title: great british bake youngest contestants shows history turn mum
story: As the youngest cohort ever to grace the screens of the programme, the millennial contestants of the Great British Bake Off have mastered the stylish cakes, biscuits and breads fit forÂ Instagram.Â When it comes to actual recipes, it seems they could require a little more help, as more than half turned to their parents and grandparents for instructions.Seven of the 13 Bake Off contestants appearing on the first episode used tried-and-tested family recipes from their mothers and grandmothers as they were asked to make a fruit cake.Others received words of wisdom from their parents over the phone before entering the tent, with one proud mother advising by text: â€œBe calm, be slow, be confident.â€This yearâ€™s contestants are the youngest group ever, with an average age of 31 and two young bakers aged 20 who were in primary school when the series first aired.Â Half of the GBBO bakers are in their 20s this yearaThe departure of 33-year-old Dan on the first episode last night brings the average age down marginally even further down, while 35-year-old Michelle was crowned Star Baker.Â Half of the bakers are in their 20s, after the production company said more young people than ever were applying as the hobby grew in popularity among Generation Z.Â During the first show, presenters Sandi Toksvig and Noel Fielding and hosts Prue Leith and Paul Hollywood teased the nervous cohort about their age, asking one whether his mother knew he was out and whether his voice had yet broken.Â Toksvig introduced the show by referring to the 13 competitors as the â€œbakerâ€™s dozenâ€, clarifying for those in the tent that the term was used by â€œmostly old peopleâ€.Asking 20-year-old Jamie how old he was, Hollywood inquired: â€œDoes your mum know youâ€™re here?â€And as Toksvig heard Henry, also 20, had not made an Angel Slice Cake before, she told him: â€œThatâ€™s because youâ€™re 12.â€After being tasked with making a fruit cake, at least seven bakers turned to recipes provided by their elders at home.Â Amelia, a 24-year-old fashion designer, plumped for her motherâ€™s technique for infusing fruit with brandy, saying she had been baking with her since she was five and still left â€œlots of washing upâ€.Â Jamie said he believed his grandmother would be happy he had adopted her recipe for simnel cake, saying: â€œI think sheâ€™s pleased Iâ€™m using it, I donâ€™t know.â€This weekâ€™s star baker Michelle used a family recipe for bara brith, while 28-year-old shop assistant Steph produced a version perfected by her late great-grandmother Rosie.Â Michael, 26, who says he was taught to bake by his mother using old, handwritten recipes passed down from her grandparents, told viewers: â€œMum text me at 5 this morning saying be calm, be title: jeffrey epstein prince andrew
story: The woman who claims Jeffrey Epstein forced her to have sex with the Duke of YorkÂ when she was 17 hasÂ urged the DukeÂ to â€œcome cleanâ€ about his dealings with the disgraced financier.Virginia Roberts-Giuffre said the Duke of York knows what he's done.Speaking outside a New York court, where she and other victims of Epstein had urged prosecutors to also question his long-standing companion Ghislaine Maxwell, a British heiress, Mrs Roberts-Giuffre said she hoped that all involved were made to answer for their involvement.Mrs Roberts-Giuffre has previously alleged in court papers in Florida that she had sex with the Duke three times, including one orgy in London, at Epstein's home, and at an orgy on his private island in the Caribbean.At 17, she would have been under the age of consent in Florida.Gloria Allred, representing several of Jeffrey Epstein&#39s alleged victims, second left, arrives with unidentified women to federal court in New Yorkâ€œI hope he comes clean about it,â€ she said.In a statement released at the weekend, the Duke of York said he did not see, witness or suspect any behaviour of the sort that led to Epstein's arrest and conviction.All the allegations about the Duke of York were struck from the court record in 2015 after being described as immaterial and impertinent by aÂ judge. The DukeÂ has always denied the allegations and any involvement.Â Lawyer David Boies, representing several of Jeffrey Epstein&#39s alleged victims arrives with Annie Farmer, second right, and Virginia GiuffreMrs Roberts-Giuffre was one of several accusers on Tuesday to mention Miss Maxwell by name in an emotionally-charged hearing, held to close the case against Epstein, who died on August 10 from suspected suicide inside a Manhattan jail.Chauntae Davies gave a harrowing account of being recruited by Miss Maxwell, and raped on his US Virgin Island home.â€œI was searching for words but all I could say was â€˜noâ€™,â€ she said. â€œBut that seemed to excite him more.â€œI ran off, my feet bloody from the rocks on the island. I cried myself to sleep that night.â€Another Epstein accuser, South African-born Sarah Ransome, told the court that she too was â€œa victim of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.â€She added: â€œWe all know that he did not act alone. We are all survivors, and the pursuit of justice should not end.â€Multiple women have filed civil lawsuits against Epstein&#39s estate since his death, saying he abused them and seeking damagesMiss Maxwell, 56, has always denied accusations of any wrongdoing, and has accused Mrs Roberts-Giuffre of lying. Mrs Roberts-Giuffre then sued for slander in a case which was settled in 2017, but whose documents were unsealed last month.Since then the British heiressâ€™s whereabouts have remained unknown, with her lawyers refusing to respond to The â€™s requests for comment. On August 14 she was reported to have been lying low in a Massachusetts mansion a day later The New York Post published a photo of her â€“ the first since 2016 - taken at a Los Angeles burger bar. The paper claimed the photo was taken earlier that week. She has not been seen since.In court on Tuesday, accuser after accuser stepped forwards to tell how Epstein and his associates inflicted immeasurable damage on their lives.Among them was the first British woman to publicly allege abuse by the late financier. AnouskaÂ de Georgiou, 42, an actress who was at school with the Duchess of Cambridge, gave a heartfelt speech about the impact of Epstein's actions.Anouska De Georgiou appeared in the 2004 film Alfie with Jude LawShe said: When I was introduced to Jeffrey Epstein I was young and full of hope and the foolishness of a teenager. Jeffrey Epstein manipulated me, coerced me and abused me.He cannot begin to fathom what he did to us. Although I think it is tragic when anyone died before their time, I am extremely relieved he will not be able to hurt any more children.Epstein was known to have travelled to the UK several times, staying at Sandringham as a guest of the Duke of York, and attending, along with the Queen, the dukeâ€™s 40th birthday party in June 2000 at Windsor Castle. Jennifer Araoz, who came forward on July 10 to accuse Epstein of raping her when she was 14, fought back tears to detail the years of torture she has suffered since her attack.â€œThe fact that I will never have the chance to face my predator in court eats away at my soul,â€ she said.â€œThis weak, evil coward will never steal our inner strength. And he will never, ever, ever steal our voice.â€Death of a financier | Jeffrey Epsteinâ€™s final daysMany of Epstein's accusers agreed with the financier's legal team that an investigation into his strange death must give answers. Reid Weingarten, Epstein's lawyer, said that Epstein's body had been moved before forensic analysis could be carried out, and demanded to know why the prison guards were reportedly refusing to testify about events on the night of his death, and why his team had not been able to view video camera footage from inside the jail.The footage, he said, was corrupted, and he wanted to know how long the system had been malfunctioning.What if the tapes only broke down when he died? Then we are in a whole different territory, he said, saying that the whole case was full of conspiracy theory galore.I think it is the understatement of the year to say the world looks and feels different to when I last stood here, he said. The elephant in the room is what happened to our client.Courtney Wild, whose July 15 testimony helped ensure Epstein was not granted bail, echoed their anger at his untimely death.â€œJeffrey Epstein sexually abused me for years, robbing me of my innocence and mental health,â€ she said. â€œJeffrey Epstein robbed myself and the other victims of our chance to confront him, one by one. For that he is a coward.â€œI feel very angry and sad. Justice has never been served in this case.â€Judge Richard Berman, presiding over the court, listened attentively as the women told their stories â€“ many of them for the first time.In the front row sat Geoffrey Berman, US attorney for the Southern District of New York, whose decision to arrest Epstein on July 6 re-opened the case.He was surrounded by a roll call of Americaâ€™s most high-powered and influential lawyers â€“ among them Al Goreâ€™s former lawyer David Boies, representing five of the victims Paul Cassell, a former federal prosecutor now working for four accusers and famed women'sÂ rights lawyer Gloria Allred, representing five women, and preparing to speak to several more.Time after time, Epstein was described as â€œsickâ€ and â€œdepravedâ€, a man who resorted to â€œinsidious and pathological violenceâ€.â€œIn 2004, at the age of 14, I was flown to Jeffrey Epsteinâ€™s Zorro Ranch in New Mexico and molested for hours,â€ said one accuser, whose anonymous statement was read out by Ms Allred.â€œWhat I remember most vividly was him explaining how beneficial this was to me as he abused me. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsEfforts&nbspto complete house purchases before&nbspBrexit are&nbspgiving the market a temporary boost, a top&nbspeconomist suggestsClick to followThe IndependentUK mortgage approvals for house purchase rose to the highest level in two and a half years in July, according to&nbspUK Finance, which represents banks and finance firms.&nbspThe number of mortgages approved for this purpose stood at 43,342 in July when adjusted for seasonal variations â€“ up 1.3 per cent on June. That is the highest number since February 2017.&nbspâ€œIt is possible that mortgage activity is being lifted by some people looking to complete their house purchases before Brexit occurs on 31 October, given the major uncertainties surrounding the UK successfully leaving the EU with a deal,â€ commented Howard Archer, chief economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club.Data from Rightmove released last week supports this interpretation. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsOverwhelming majority of companies had offices in the UK but have now either relocated to the Netherlands or established offices thereClick to followThe IndependentBrexit has lured almost 100 companies away from Britain and into the Netherlands as they look for a new base in the EU, according to a Dutch government agency.&nbspBy the end of last week, 98 firms had set up shop in the Netherlands specifically due to the UKâ€™s uncertain position in the bloc and a growing risk of a no-deal Brexit on 31 October, said Michiel Bakhuizen,&nbspa spokesperson&nbspfor the Netherlands Foreign Investment Agency (NFIA).The overwhelming majority of those companies had offices in Britain but, since the 2016 referendum, have either relocated to the Netherlands or established offices there. The rest wanted to move into the UK but changed their plans due to Brexit.&nbspAnother 325 firms are thinking of setting up in the Netherlands for the same reason, the representative&nbspsaid. Both sets of businesses include British firms as well as those from North America, Asia and Australia.â€œBrexit undeniably has economic implications for international businesses because they do business everywhere in Europe,â€ said Jeroen Nijland, NFIA commissioner.&nbspâ€œThe ongoing growing uncertainty in the United Kingdom, and the increasingly clearer possibility of a no deal, is causing major economic unrest for these companies. That is the highest number since February 2017.&nbspâ€œIt is possible that mortgage activity is being lifted by some people looking to complete their house purchases before Brexit occurs on 31 October, given the major uncertainties surrounding the UK successfully leaving the EU with a deal,â€ commented Howard Archer, chief economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club.Data from Rightmove released last week supports this interpretation. House sales jumped 6.1 per cent over the month to 10 August compared with a year ago. The rest wanted to move into the UK but changed their plans due to Brexit.&nbspAnother 325 firms are thinking of setting up in the Netherlands for the same reason, the representative&nbspsaid. Both sets of businesses include British firms as well as those from North America, Asia and Australia.â€œBrexit undeniably has economic implications for international businesses because they do business everywhere in Europe,â€ said Jeroen Nijland, NFIA commissioner.&nbspâ€œThe ongoing growing uncertainty in the United Kingdom, and the increasingly clearer possibility of a no deal, is causing major economic unrest for these companies. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsElon Musk hopes to ferry people to the Red Planet in 2024Click to followThe Independent TechSpaceX has successfully tested its Starhopper rocket, which it hopes will one day transport up to 100 people to Mars.The test flight in Boca Chica Beach in Texas lasted just one minute but saw the spacecraft lift 150 metres into the air before landing on a separate launch pad.It is the second Starhopper test in the space of a month, with the first test resulting in the rocket failing to launch.&nbspThe success of the latest test means this was the last flight for Starhopper, as more advanced test flights are planned for&nbspthe future.The Starhopper tests were designed to better understand the feasibility of SpaceXâ€™s&nbspStarship rocket â€“ a giant spacecraft that the private space firm aims to use to ferry people around the Solar System.Starship is being built to launch from Earth on top of SpaceXâ€™s Super Heavy rocket. Once it arrives to Mars it will use its own onboard engines to navigate its way safely to the Martian surface. One of the biggest breakthroughs of the Starhopper and Starship is that they run on liquid methane and liquid oxygen, which can both be found and manufactured on Mars.Created with Sketch.Best Nasa pictures of the month - August 2019 Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.When stars like the Sun grow advanced in age, they expand and glow red. Iain Duncan Smith, David Davis, John Redwood, Steve Baker and Mark Francois have all said the backstop is not the only thing that makes the withdrawal agreement unacceptable. title: children werewolf syndrome contaminated medicine
story: The youngsters were being given omeprazole, which is used to treat acid reflux and indigestion, as part of a formula.But health officials have said that the medicine was tainted with minoxidil - an alopecia remedy, according to local reports.Its caused the children to develop hypertrichosis - a rare condition that causes excessive hair growth anywhere on the persons body.The Spanish Agency for Medicines and Health Products has ordered that several batches from Farma-QuÃ­mica Sur SL, were withdrawn from circulation on July .Its believed that the Malaga-based pharmaceuticals company imported the affected meds from India.According to the Granada Hoy, health bosses have confirmed that the item was contaminated at its original source.Most of the affected batch - from lot    - is now said to have been recalled and any missing packets are being tracked down.But parents are being warned to seek medical helptheir child has been given the formula and check with the pharmacy to seethey purchased from the contaminated lot.It can affect both women and men, but itâ€™s extremely rare.The abnormal hair growth may cover the face and body or occur in small patches.Hypertrichosis can appear at birth or develop over time.The causes of hypertrichosis arenâ€™t well understood, though there is a form of the disease that tends to run in families.Congenital hypertrichosis may be caused by reactivation of genes that cause hair growth.The genes that caused extensive hair growth in early man have â€œshut downâ€ during the course of evolution.By a mistake that still has no known cause, these hair-growth genes â€œturn onâ€ while a baby is still in the womb.Hypertrichosis has no cure, and you canâ€™t do anything to prevent the congenital form of the disease.The risk of certain forms of acquired hypertrichosis may be lowered by avoiding certain medications, such as minoxidil.Treating hypertrichosis involves the removal of hair through a iety of short-term methods including shaving, chemical epilation, waxing, plucking and hair bleaching.Long-term solutions include electrolysis and laser surgery.Source: HealthlineÂ Theyre also advised to take them to a doctor immediatelytheyve noticed an excessive hair growth after consuming omeprazole.Health sources told El Pais also said that when the babies stopped taking the medicine their hair growth subsided.

title: boris has been a revelation since he took over brexit but signing away powers to get it over the line could cost him his job
story: Delivering on the referendum ought to make Nigel Farageâ€™s Brexit Party redundant and ensure a Tory election win. We do not see Brussels nor the Irish PM scrapping the backstop they have treated as holy writ.But when his own allies like Iain Duncan Smith warn him not to be satisfied solely with that, Boris must listen.WHOâ€™S up for more years of bitter Brexit ision and political paralysis Not Leavers, who were sick of it long ago and are furious their vote hasnâ€™t been fulfilled. title: remainers porkie pies trade deals
story: By drawing his excited opponents into making accusations about yet more of Borisâ€™s â€œporky piesâ€, he has skilfully drawn attention to the point he really wanted to make â€” that there are huge global opportunities for British food exportersonly we are prepared to make concessions in opening up our own food markets to the world.In fact,we start exporting pork pies to the Far East we will only be ing to what we were doing more than  years ago.In , Melton Mowbray bakers Evans  Hill reported they had received a large order of pork pies from Borneo â€” which is even further from Britain than Thailand.If we could do it then, without modern refrigeration, we can surely do it now. As Boris was arguing, the real barriers to trade are not practical ones â€” they are taxes and regulations.Remainers continually lecture us on the benefits of free trade with the EU â€” and they are right to do so. Hardly anyone really wants to leave without a deal. If we do have to take that route it will surely not be long before discussions on a free trade deal recommence.Yet those same Remainers bizarrely retreat in horror when anyone suggests we do a free trade deal with the US. â€œBut weâ€™ll have to eat chlorinated chicken,â€ they complain, as well as GM â€œFrankensteinâ€ food.As shown by their failure yesterday to agree on a common course of action to thwart Brexit, Remainers are bumbling along in a state of confusion.But nothing demonstrates this better than their contradictory approach to free trade. They seem to think it a great benefit to the country when conducted with the EU, but a route to national disastercarried out with any other country.The charge that anyone will be forced to eat chlorinated chicken or GM foods is, needless to say, a far bigger porky pie than anything Boris has said on the subject.It is far from certain that a Johnson Government, when engaged in trade talks with the US, will make the concessions allowing these products into UK markets, butit does, then UK shoppers will continue to have a choice.They will still be able to buy chicken produced in Britain or the EU, or they will be able to choose to eat American chicken.I certainly have no fear of eating chicken which has been washed in chlorine. The idea that it is â€œdangerousâ€ has been thoroughly debunked. Each of us ingests far more chlorine through drinking water than we ever would do through eating US-produced chicken.As for GM foods, we already eat them, vegans especially. The EU allows imports of GM soyafor simple practical reasons. Most of it is grown in the Americas and too many growers there use GM seed for non-GM soya to be sold as a separate product.If we want free trade we are not going to achieve it just by persuading other countries to open their markets to us. No, we will have to make the concession of opening our markets to them too. But there is no reason to be frightened.True, there are some products which need to be banned from sale for genuine health and safety reasons. But most of the EUâ€™s food product standards are really just a form of protectionism in disguise, dreamed up to block competition for European farmers.If we do post-Brexit trade deals with the US and other countries â€” and in the process do away with the EUâ€™s protectionist tarfs and product standards â€” some UK producers would suffer.But others would prosper as they enjoyed access to new export markets. Overall, as is almost always the case when trade barriers are taken down, we would benefit. Strong industries would grow and consumers would enjoy greater choice and lower prices.Borisâ€™s vision of a global British pork pie industry shows the dference between him and the political opponents who spent much of yesterday scheming over how to stop him taking Britain out of the EU.While his glass is half full, theirs is half empty.They are driven by a pathological fear of le outside the EU.It is not that they have any great enthusiasm for the EU. After all, I havenâ€™t heard one of them make a convincing case why the EU is an institution to be admired. It is just that they have a lack of ambition for Britain and so cling to EU membership.After meeting for several hours yesterday, what did the likes of Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer and Jo Swinson come up with That they want to extend Article  yet further, to prolong yet again the endless drt which unsettled markets and put off investment.Thanks to the Remain lobbyâ€™s endless infighting and self-indulgent argument over who it would like as a caretaker Prime Minister, that is exactly what is overwhelmingly likely to happen on October .Â Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. We also werent aware of these rules before we went as everywhere  seems to allow picnics.Zahira said the family ended up spending an additional Â£ on food outside the park.She said: Being Muslims we have specic dietary needs, so we found it easier and cheaper to go to a halal takeaway nearby for lunch.We tried to explain why we had brought our own lunch, but the woman at the entrance to the park saidwe didnt dispose of them we werent allowed into the park.We had saved so hard for this day trip. We spent over Â£ on tickets, Â£ on fuel, Â£ on food and drinks in advance to take with us, then another Â£ inside the park on drinks and merchandise, as well as Â£ for food at the takeaway.We didnt want to keep our food in the lockers - it was a hot day. It was diabolical and unacceptable.I found it disgusting that they wouldnt allow us to take our food in. That means MPs face a race against time to thwart the Prime Minister taking the UK out of the EU without a deal. Johnson says he wants an opportunity to set up new bills to â€˜level upâ€™ spending on his priorities, including the NHS, education and policing. But his plan will also dramatically cut down the amount of time MPs have to block Johnson pressing forward with a chaotic no-deal Brexit . Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about Boris Johnson â€™s new plan - and what it means for Brexit. What is Boris Jonson doing - and why does it mean shutting down Parliament  Heâ€™s setting the date for a Queenâ€™s Speech and State Opening of Parliament . This effectively reboots Parliament, setting off a new â€˜sessionâ€™ and shutting down the old one. This usually happens every year - but it doesnâ€™t have to, and Theresa May chose not to have a Queenâ€™s Speech in -, so sheâ€™d have more time to push Brexit plans through. That means weaposve now had the longest gap between Queenaposs Speeches for more than  years. To trigger a Queenaposs Speech Parliament has to have a short break, which usually lasts a few days. And when MPs , the slate is clear. Any legislation that was in the process of passing through Parliament is cancelled and MPs start the new session effectively from scratch.  Â  What does proroguing Parliament mean  aposProrouguingapos means to suspend a session of Parliament without dissolving it. So ending one session and kicking off a new one with a Queenaposs Speech. Rebooting Parliament. What is the Queenâ€™s Speech   Itâ€™s theannual address given by the Monarch to MPs and peers, opening the new session of Parliament. Itâ€™s used by the Prime Minister to outline the Governmentâ€™s legislative programme for the upcoming session. How long would Parliament be suspended for   That hasnâ€™t been revealed, but hereâ€™s the most likely scenario. Parliament is expected tofrom recess on Tuesday September . Itâ€™s then expected to sit until September  or , when it would break up for party conference season. Usually, Parliament wouldstraight away after the end of Conservative Party Conference, which finishes on October . Whatâ€™s being suggested is that the conference recess be extended for another full week, ing for the Queenâ€™s speech on Monday October . How would this affect plan to stop no deal   It massively slashes the amount of time MPs have to pass any kind of blocking measures through Parliament. Letâ€™s assume the Commons sits Monday to Friday - which it doesnâ€™t always, but letâ€™s assume it would in a crunch. If the original timeline were to take place, there would be a maximum of eight sitting days before the conference recess. And assuming they ed the Monday after Tory conference, there would be scope for  sitting days between then and the October  deadline. Thatâ€™s  days in which an anti-no-deal coalition could work on ways to block it. Now,thereâ€™s a Queenâ€™s Speech on October , in all likelihood Parliament would stay in recess for the week before. There are usually five full days of debate following a Queenâ€™s Speech - and another two days of votes on the speech on October -. This would make it exceptionally dficult to schedule any further business in the Commons during that time. So that would leave just seven potential sitting days between conferences and the Brexit deadline - and just  in total. Thereâ€™s also the small matter of the European Council meeting on October , which will be the PMâ€™s last opportunity to seal a new deal with the EU. Boris Johnson this morning said there will be â€œample timeâ€ to debate Brexit before and after the October  meeting.  She can, but she wonâ€™t. The Queenâ€™s role in this is almost entirely ceremonial. Even her speech to Parliament is written by the Government. Constitutional experts have said The Queen would do everything possible to avoid becoming involved in any political battle the country finds itself in.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave is gripping The Arctic, melting away Greenlandâ€™s ice sheet on an unprecedented scale and threatening a global rise in sea levels â€“ an urgent reminder of the climate crisis we are now all facing. Kids splashing each other in the sea and locals wearing t-shirts were unheard of here in August  years ago. But now, alongside teenage girls wearing skirts to school and increasing mosquitoes, it is a common occurrence for the residents of Qaanaaq, in north-west Greenland, one of the worldâ€™s most northerly cities situated  miles north of the Arctic Circle. Greenland, the worldâ€™s largest island at almost three times the size of France, is now living with extreme environmental changes which could see the Arctic Sea free of ice by no action is taken.  Â  I travelled to Greenland, home to just , people, last week to see first hand the drastic changes to conditions and to understand why it matters to us all. Away from headlines about melting ice caps and pictures of underfed polar bears unable to stalk seals on flimsy ice forced to invade towns for food, I found a community battling to adjust. Living alongside a backdrop of eerily beautul icebergs and utterly terrying melting sea ice and retreating glaciers is having a devastating impact on species, habitats and human le. This is the frontline of climate change.  Â  Three-quarters say they have personally experienced the impact of global warming in their daily lives, from coping with dangerous sea ice journeys to having hunting sled dogs put down for economic reasons due to shorter winters - with many unaware of the full impact. While we may shrug at the decline of traditional hunting, it is impossible to visit Greenland and not be profoundly affected by their tales of how climate change has upturned their world in just a single generation. Families have been torn apart, livelihoods threatened giving us all an insight into the scale of the battle now facing humanity. â€œIf all of Greenlandâ€™s ice were to melt, it would raise global sea levels by fett meaning cities like London, Sydney and New York underwater and the whole of Bangladesh would disappear,â€ says Mark Wright, director of science at WWF, who accompanied the Daily Mirror to the Arctic. â€œThis is not science fiction. This is the reality of climate change.  Â  â€œIt is happening now â€“ and here in accelerated terms â€“ providing a crucial insight into what we will all face unless urgently tackle this now. Sea ice now forms here two months later and melts one month earlier - as temperatures rise twice as fast as the global average. This summer has seen more than  wildfires in the Arctic Circle devastating once pristine forests, turning them from precious carbon dioxide absorbing sponges into giant new emitters of greenhouse gases. The country is also experiencing record-breaking temperatures. In mid-June, along the eastern coast it was C warmer than the - average. Just as western Europe has baked in a heatwave with record temperatures at the end of July, the hot air moved as far north as Greenland with the gauge hitting C on August . The average high is around C.  Journeys around the coast which took three weeks in the s because of the sea ice now take a single day. Perched beneath the worldâ€™s second largest ice cap after Antarctica, nothing other than black moss and lichen grow here. Fourth fths of Greenland is buried under an ice sheet two miles thick, much of it three million years old. But in the blink of an eye in geological terms it has begun melting â€“ and much faster than climate change models predicted. Around % is affected, including higher elevations that only rarely see temperatures climb above freezing. In July alone  billion tonnes of meltwater poured into the Atlantic â€“ enough to raise sea levels by .mm. We take a small fishing boat out with Joseph Manumina, , who points to a glacier he used to cross in a five-metre sled pulled by  huskies in the winter.  Â  But like thousands of others here, the fourth-generation hunter has been forced to abandon his family trade and is now a fisherman. Joseph stops his boat beside the Hiawatha glacier and points out when he was young it stretched hundreds of metres further into the fjord. â€œThe land you can now see was not visible at all a few years ago. But heavy rains came in  and changed the landscape for good,â€ he said. Last year, thanks to signicant melting, scientists discovered a -mile-long crater â€“ the first to be found under ice â€“ believed to be a direct result of a meteorite impact. While similar melting effects are being measured in the southern hemisphere, the Greenland sheet may be uniquely vulnerable, lying much further from the chill of the pole than Antarcticaâ€™s. Scattered across  small towns and approximately  villages, all situated on a narrow coastal strip, Greenlandâ€™s residents have often been overlooked by data science. But a first-ever national survey has examined the human impact of the climate emergency â€“ showing % of islanders interviewed fully accept that the climate crisis is happening. The Greenlandic Perspectives Survey was carried out by the University of Copenhagenâ€™s Center for Social Data Science, the Kraks Fond Institute for Urban Economic Research and the University of Greenland.  Â  Lead author Kelton Minor said: â€œThe Arctic is a bellwether for the unequal impact of global warming on social and economic systems. â€œAs countries struggle to limit future risks and overall warming to .C many Arctic and Greenlandic residents are already living in regional climates that have changed by more than this, in less than a letime. â€œTherein lies the paradox: while satellites and sensors monitor the surface of Greenlandâ€™s ice sheet, chase icebergs and scan sea ice daily, relatively little is known about what the residents of Greenland think about their changing surroundings.â€ July st was the biggest melt day since at least , when % of sheet experienced melt. Studies found ice melt periods like the one seen seven years ago typically occur about every  years. One occuring so quickly is an important sign how quickly the climate is changing, warn experts. â€œThis is a double edged sword, says Mark Wright, director of Science at WWF. â€œWhat we do here in the UK, they way we live our lives by burning fossil fuels, is speeding up the change. â€œAt the same time this is affecting Greenland and other Arctic countries. But what happens here will also affect what happens at home in terms of our weather patterns and security in coastal areas. â€œThis is why we have to take action and now. â€œWe donâ€™t have long left to cap this rapid change that weâ€™ve never seen before in human history.â€ The rapid melting is also opening up new shipping routes and mining opportunities for deposits of rare-earth elements used in technology previously buried under ice sheets hundreds of metres thick.  It has sparked the interest of American President Donald Trump with an attempt to buy it, while China already has a mine on the island. While it is impossible to put a price on the territory, estimates range from . trillion to .trillion depending on the mining potential - believed to be enough to meet % of the worldâ€™s demand in the next  years. Trump may have cancelled his trip to Denmark for now but his suggestion is a marker of the fact Greenland is also now at the heart of a new battle for supremacy in the Arctic, where superpower competition is heating up as fast as the ice is melting.

story: John Cooper Clarke is ready to rock# and Dundee should be afraid, very afraid.He may be in his older years, but he is not holding back.And the man known as the punk poet has vowed to perform in his unmistakable style â€“ machine gun delivery studded with factory floor language.The rasping Salford accent is still there and the humour as cutting as a surgeonâ€™s scalpel.And for the real devotees, John has teased them by telling the Tele exclusively that he has begun planning his memoirs.In typical fashion he says: â€œI havenâ€™t kept a f****** diary, but I have got a good memory.â€œIn fact, my memory is long and my vengeance is total.â€To the musicians and celebs who have crossed JCC in the past, start praying now because the master could even recall the gig I saw him perform at Strathclyde University in the early s and who was playing on the same bill.For the record, it was Siouxsie and the Banshees â€“ and I couldnâ€™t remember that, despite being a few years younger than the man.Back in the day, John easily recalls everyone being angry young men and women. The hate for Thatcher was pure and the depth of feeling surged through concerts and rallies.He says with a chuckle: â€œThem were the days.â€œWe thought it was bad then, but everything can get worse, as we see now. Itâ€™s a case of careful what you wish for.â€œI donâ€™t get involved in politics now, like I say when didnâ€™t anyone complain about politicians â€œCan you point me to a golden era where# everybody liked being ruled  F***ing never!â€œBut there are some real creeps nowadays. But then again I expect the worst from any politician.â€So what can fans in Dundee expect when John rolls into town for his show at the cityâ€™s Gardyne Theatre on Saturday October  Without missing a beat he fires back: â€œA right f****** good night!â€œAnd they can expect more of the same#and then some. There will be a few classics and there will maybe be a few extra poems.â€œThen I will add a bit of fun and I can guarantee â€“ solid, copper-plated guarantee â€“ that everybody is going to leave with a smile on their face.â€John has fond memories of Dundee and spoke of savouring the atmosphere of a waterfront hotel and added: â€œI love coming to Scotland and Dundee. Iâ€™ve been many times and the reaction of the crowd is great.â€œI was here last year and saw the VA which is fabulous. I know of DC Thomson and the Sunday Post, the Beano and the Dandy plus Oor Wullie.â€œMaybe I will buy one of those sculptures.â€Posh hotels and venues seem a world away from the clubs and student venues of the s with smoke-filled rooms and plastic tumblers full of warm beer.He used to travel to the shows on public transport and chuckles at the memory.John said: â€œYeah, long time ago now, mate. Now I have a driver and I am too old for public transport.â€œBut I still love doing live gigs. Itâ€™s smashing. Anywhere where thereâ€™s people is greatIâ€™m doing my stuff.â€œI am working on my book of poems right now. Itâ€™s called â€˜The Luckiest Man Aliveâ€™ and Iâ€™m also working on the memoirs. vw, px"  â€œI am thinking of calling that â€˜I Wanna Be Yoursâ€™ after the Arctic Monkeys. I just hope to live long enough to finish it.â€œBut I am not finishing up any time soon. I have never even thought about that. I am not retiring, not yet and not in the foreseeable future.â€John has the tour to contend with first and is also lining up some television work.And at the age of  there is definitely no holding him back. So look out for many more tours to come from the man who wants to be yours.

title: dundee 0 ict 0 dee held by caley in dens draw
story: Dundee had to settle for a share of the spoils as they were held by Inverness Caley Thistle in stuffy conditions at Dens Park.On a hot and sticky afternoon neither side hit top gear and the goalless outcome was a fair,frustrating, result.Dundee welcomed back striker Kane Hemmings after his missed the narrow Betfred Cup defeat against Aberdeen on Sunday because of a minor knock.And on the bench was teenager Josh McPake, signed on loan from Rangers earlier in the week.Missing was midfielder Jamie Ness, a late call off after he was laid low by illness.The home side made the early running, but when Aaron Doran skipped past a couple of challenges and shot from  yards, it took a fine stop by Jack Hamilton to keep the scores level.A good passing move at the other end saw the ball worked to Danny Johnson. His shot was well struck, but Mark Ridgers in the Caley goal saved well.Both teams were knocking the ball around without creating much, but Dee skipper Paul McGowan went close when he curled a -yarder just over in the st minute.Dundee were having a good spell and shortly after, Declan McDaid saw a fine free kick well saved by Ridgers.Two minutes before the break Shaun Byrne set up Hemmings for a shot, but he pulled his angled drive a foot wide.Just over two minutes into the second half Doran went close again for the visitors when he shot inches over from the edge of the area.As Dundee looked for the opener, Johnson saw a low shot deflected just wide as he tried to capitalise on a James Keatings error.The home side were working hard to break the deadlock, but for all their effort chances were few and far between.In a bid add that vital spark in the final third, on the hour mark James McPake handed a debut to his namesake Josh as he replaced Johnson.It was clear the home team were not prepared to settle for a point and shortly after another attacker, Andrew Nelson, was sent on for teenager Fin Robertson.With seven minutes left Hemming missed a glorious chance when he headed over unchallenged from a McDaid free kick.And that meant a point was all Dundee were going to get.

title: no derby talk at dens says cammy kerr as they focus on inverness clash
story: Thereâ€™s absolutely no derby talk at Dens Park says Cammy Kerr as first of all Dundee get ready for a tough Championship test against Inverness tomorrow.The Dark Blues welcome their Highland opponents to Dens Park for the second time this season after knocking John Robertsonâ€™s side out of the Betfred Cup last month.The attention for plenty fans, of both dark blue and tangerine persuasion, has already switched to next Fridayâ€™s derby.Kerr accepts thereâ€™s nothing that can be done about that but insists the players are doing no such thing.He told the Tele: â€œEveryone  must be thinking of that and it can be hard sometimes to ignore the distractions with everything that goes on seeing online that people have got their tickets and stuff like that.â€œBut as players we know we have a really tough game against Inverness first tomorrow.â€œThatâ€™s our focus and once thatâ€™s done we move on to the next one.â€œThatâ€™s why we are supposed to be professional football players because you have to stay professional.â€œYou have to stay focused, know what the aims are and that is only looking at tomorrow.â€œItâ€™s all about getting a result tomorrow.â€œWe are under no illusions how good Inverness are.â€œWe had a really tough game against them in the Betfred Cup, though I thought we were the better team.â€œThey are a really good side and John Robertson always has them set up well, so we need to make sure our tactics and performance are spot on.â€The warning for the Dark Blues is that, by Invernessâ€™ recent history in this ision as one of the strongest teams, theyâ€™ll be better than they were during that - Weâ€™re still hurting, though, because it was a scalp we could have taken and we were a couple of minutes from taking it.â€œTo do that would have been great and the sucker punch at the end killed that but the boys are happy with the performance. It runs to  pages, and must have taken signicant time and money to produce.It relies heavily on community participation and the Third Sector Interface .While it was being prepared the HSCP was in the process of getting rid of volunteer forums, TSI was shedding staff and Guided Self Help was being transferred to the NHS Mental Health Team, while essential services are still dependent on successful bids for money.Planning must not be a substitute for provision. title: a note of chamber music coming to crear
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe UKâ€™s leading string orchestra, the Scottish Ensemble , has announced the first half of Scottish tourÂ  # and Argyll is on the list of venues.The ensemble will perform Mendelssohn and Enescuâ€™s stunning octets, and will be led by the outstanding Norwegian violinist Marianne Thorsen.Though written for just eight instruments, both of these sophisticated works have the drama, richness and depth of a full-blown symphony. They also make for an excellently contrasting pair.From Mendelssohnâ€™s exuberant opening bars, we are swept through music that is complex yet captivatingly, joyously melodic throughout, while Enescuâ€™s is moody, breathlessly dramatic and, in parts, simply volcanic.Guest directed by Marianne Thorsen, SE will explore the specic charm of seeing a small group of musicians performing live. With fewer instruments, the fabric of the music becomes more tangible, subtle shts in mood may have a new-found presence, and pieces you think you know well might offer surprising new colours when heard live. With fewer musicians on stage, it is easier to follow each inidual path and witness the beautul alchemy of eight artists creating something together.Thorsen is an acclaimed soloist and passionate chamber musician. Former leader of the Nash Ensemble, she regularly performs with Norwayâ€™s Trondheim Soloists, one of the founding ensembles of The Bridge network and festival.The first half of the tour, which is called Chamber Notes, will call at Crear Studio, Kilberry, on August , followed by a performance at Mull Theatre, Tobermory, on August  before moving on to Inverness and Dundee.Other Scottish dates, including Edinburgh and Glasgow, are programmed for February .PIC:Marianne Thorsen. no_aMarianne Thorsen

title: letters to the editor august 16 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to record my thanks to everyone who contributed to the running of the Mid Argyll Show this year.It is great for visitors to see these traditions and talent brought together and seeing young people participating in events assuring that these customs are in safe hands for the future.Thank you again to all involved in running the show.Councillor Anne HornSir,I read with some interest that a new dentist was coming to town in Lochgilphead to set up a practice, which I am sure we look forward to.The local NHS trust cannot seem to lure one to the area to work at the Mid Argyll Hospital practice, which I think is unfortunate for all concerned. There is the possibility that those on the local list who are currently treated well by the dental department at the hospital maybe still seen by the dentist and her staff, but I would like this to be confirmed by the local NHS trust.Brian MacDonald, CrinanSir,Hundreds ofÂ people across Scotland have been helped through their exam results by aÂ localÂ group of Skills Development Scotlandcareers advisers.Based across the north of Scotland, the advisers were part of a team taking calls at the SDS Exam Results Helpline from am on results day.The helpline is a vital service, supporting young people and their families at what can be one of the most stressful times of their lives.Expert advice and guidance is available all year round, not just on results day.Our professionally qualied careers advisers are working in every state secondary school in Scotland and from our network of high street centres across the country.In schools, careers services are delivered one-to-one, in classrooms and at school events across all year groups, supporting young people to develop the skills to make informed career decisions throughout their lives. There is also support for parents and carers.At SDS centres customers can get information, advice and guidance about jobs, the local labour market, training courses and apprenticeships as well as how to prepare for interviews and help with CVs and applications.The work of SDS careers advisers in schools and centres is supported by Scotlandâ€™s careers website myworldofwork, where you can access advice  hours a day. It is packed with career information, advice and tools such as the CV builder. There is also a dedicated exam results section.Details of the local SDS centres are available at myworldofwork centres and information about events and opportunities is also available on Facebook.Pauline Graham, Project Manager for the SDS Exam Results HelplineSir,I had a great time at this year#s Islay Show. It was fantastic to speak to so many of my constituents.It was also wonderful to see many local business stalls promoting Islay#s dynamic and booming economy.The show was well attended with lots of families, both local and visitors, having a fun day out and luckily the sun was shining most of the day.A huge thanks to all the organisers and everyone  who contributed to the event.Councillor Alastair RedmanSir,I have real concerns about the deteriorating condition of some Argyll cemeteries.Constituents from Islay recently joined Councillor Alastair Redman in highlighting the poor upkeep of cemeteries in the area he represents.Councillor Redman reported that there were also problems at other cemeteries in his ward, including the cemetery at Carradale in East Kintyre.I understand that Argyll and Bute Council confirmed that they now, at last, have plans in place to address the problems at Kilnaughton.It remains disappointing, however, that things are allowed to deteriorate to the extent that the maintenance of cemeteries has become a matter of public concern.Frankly, it is very surprising that a cemetery where interments are actually still taking place has been undermined in this way and there must surely be an obligation to ensure this doesnâ€™t happen.My experience is that communities in the Highlands and Islands pay special regard to the final resting places of fellow members of their communities and will be perplexed to discover that they appear to be uncared-for.Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands MSP

title: lets not negotiate away scotland the brand
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowIf there is an accusation that could not be thrown at Ruth Watson, founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign, it is that she lacks enthusiasm.The Argyllshire Advertiser caught up with the founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign at the recent Mid Argyll Show.She is a firm believer that Scotland#s iconic food and drink products should be protected from imitation where. The means forÂ  protection is the European Union PGIdesignation, to promote and protect names of quality agricultural products and foodstuffs.Ruth, an experienced journalist, explained: #I became concerned about two years ago when, during Japan EU Canadatrade talks, the UK government did not submit one PGI for protection.#Across Europe, , food names were protected. It worries me greatly.#She continued: #I am also concerned about how hard it is becoming to source local food and drink. I live in rural Angus, and the carrots grown down the road from me started le just as Angus carrots, but they went away for packaging and came back as Great British carrots. Technically that is correct, butwe believe in supporting local farmers and making clear choices about food miles and quality, this is ridiculous.#She stressed: #This is not a protectionist campaign. I welcome trade with any part of the world as long as the farm assured quality is there.##Keep Scotland the Brand is about valuing the integrity of our food and drink and recognising that Scotland is the brand. Across the world, people recognise Scotland as a quality brand.#One in five Scots is employed in the food and drink sector, so it is vitally important to keep our brand quality.#We trust the food on our shelves at the moment. Butthe trade deals being proposed go through we#ll end up with a multi-tiered system of quality. If the Americans get the trade deal they want, the high food standards we have are really only going to be accessible to those who can afford to pay.#It#s bad enough people having to go to food banks to survive, without people not knowing why their kids are getting ill.Ruth Watson is keen to emphasise that Keep Scotland the Brand is not a political campaign and it#s not about Brexit.#It is a campaign looking at the realities of what is before us,# she says. #I think that we have to look with some alarm at the trade deals that have been done. The UK government just has not protected our food brands.##I do this campaign on a voluntary basis from my kitchen table,# she went on. #Many people do not know what is coming. Food is treated as a commodity rather than something we should be grateful for every day, that is how successful our farmers have been.#I just believe thatfarming fails, my community is going under.##I#ve been talking to elected representatives, I go round shows. I#ll talk to anyone about this.#But what can ordinary people do Ruth is quite clear. #Get out there and talk to each other, spread the word on social media, speak to politicians.#But most of all support our local farmers.#

title: 43-year-old-woman-admits-causing-ambulance-disturbance-a7
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered for a Hawick woman involved in a fracas while being transported to Borders General Hospital.Grace Smith, , of Fisher Avenue, pleaded guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in an ambulance on the A at Ashkirk on November .She admitted shouting and swearing, struggling with police officers and running from an ambulance on an unlit road during the hours of darkness.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said the accused reported that she had been assaulted by being struck in the face in a Hawick public house.She had complained of a sore face and was intoxicated but there was no evidence of an assault.The fiscal said that due to the circumstances an ambulance was summoned and it was considered appropriate to take Smith to Borders General Hospital.But at .pm when the ambulance was about five miles south of Hawick paramedics called the police because she was being unruly.Mr Fraser said the ambulance had to stop because of her conduct and Smith jumped out of the vehicle and was running along the road and ambulance personnel ran after her and escorted her back to the ambulance.Mr Fraser said: "Police officers arrived on the scene and her behaviour was described as emotional and volatile. She started struggling with police and had to be placed in handcuffs."He added that Smith stated thatshe was let out she would kill herself.A cigarette lighter was found in her underwear with which she intended to use to cut herself.Sentence was deferred until September .

title: council-backs-plans-return-jim-clark-rally
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is backing plans for theof the Jim Clark Rally later this year.Organisers of the popular event have earmarked the weekend of November  and  for the closed roads race.Following the deaths of three people in  a major investigation into closed road motor sport was launched by the Scottish Government.Earlier this year organisers were given the green light to start preparations once more for hosting the event after new legislation was passed - but they still requirepermission from Scottish Borders Council.Senior councillors havetoday confirmed that it is minded to approve plans.A recent local authority consultation on the organiserrsquos plan received more than  responses, with an overwhelming majority supporting the proposals for  rally stages, using four routes, over the two days.Councillor Euan Jardine said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank everyone who took part in the consultation."A number of specic points were raised and these have been passed to the event organiser and discussed through our Safety Advisory Group meetings.ldquoWe are all operating under new legislation in planning for this event and that has its own requirements and a signicant amount of work is still required before we could provide formal approval and a Motor Sport Order for the event.ldquoHowever, we are confident that the outstanding matters can be dealt with through the intense planning process that is ongoing and for the event to take place as currently proposed.The Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Group process enables the local authority and other concerned groups to discuss event plans, including safety arrangements.Councillor Mark Rowley said: ldquoWhilst a smaller event than in previous years, there is no doubt that a Jim Clark Rally in November would provide an economic boost to the Berwickshire area, and the Scottish Borders generally."This would be particularly welcome outwith the normal visitor season and would be a great finale to the year which has seen the successful opening of the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum in Duns.ldquoThe economic impact of the proposed event is, as written in the new legislation, a consideration for the Council in assessing whether it should go ahead, however our priority, first and foremost, is that it is as safe as possible for all involved.

title: beyond-borders-celebrating-10-years
story: TOP writers, broadcasters, politicians and artists are heading to Innerleithen this weekend for the Beyond Borders International Festival.The event which is celebrating its th anniversary, is being held at Traquair House.A number of activities will be on throughout the weekend in the main marquee in front of the house.And in the old walled garden where there will be music, exhibitions, film, food tastings, meditation sessions and yoga.The global impact of climate change will take centre stage throughout the festival including a  discussion addressing the vital role of women in climate action a youth climate change summit with school strikers taking part in discussions and events and Carbon Casualties, a photography exhibition from the New York Times which is on display in the garden.Other programme highlights include the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon former UN Special Envoy to Syria, Staffan de Mistura and journalists Lindsey Hilsum Razia Iqbal Allan Little Jim Naughtie and Sarah Smith.For a historical perspective, Professor Bettany Hughes Sir Tom Devine Sir Hew Strachan and Rosemary Goring will all be appearing.The event will also welcome remarkable female cultural leaders from Afghanistan, Kashmir, Pakistan, Syria and Yemen to take part in sessions on the art of peace building.This festival which also includes walks, storytelling and bike rides, began  years ago as the inspiration of Mark Muller Stuart QC who lives at Traquair with his we, Catherine.He told us: "The festival proves that the thirst for human debate and the desire to listen to the first-hand experiences and stories of others remains undiminished notwithstanding the rise of the digital age."What better place to do it than in the tranquil setting of Traquair in the Scottish Borders."

title: vandals-target-primary-schools-days-pupils-return
story: POLICE have launched an investigation after vandals ransacked a Peebles primary school - just days before pupils were due tofrom the summer holidays.Parents of Halyrude Primary School were horried after discovering the destruction caused by thugs at the weekend.Vandals undermined months of hard work by fundraisers and volunteers by destroying the polytunnel as well as the plants inside.Not content with ripping apart the tunnel, they also smashed a window in the school building and pushed over all the new picnic benches.The culprits also appear to have tried to force entry to a locked shed.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: "We are investigating following a report of vandalism to a primary School in Peebles."The incident happened sometime overnight between Saturday and Sunday, August  and , and resulted in a window being broken and a vegetable patch being disturbed."Inquiries to identy those responsible are ongoing."The school purchased the new greenhouse structure after landing a windfall from the Tesco Bags of Help earlier this year.The project was made possible with help from members of the Peebles CAN team and parent volunteers.And green-fingered pupils were hoping to harvest ingredients for lunches, but vandals have destroyed those plans.Locals took to the Peeblesshire Community Vandalism page to voice their disgust and dismay, with offers to help to clean up the destruction pouring in from residents.Parents said there was a large amount of broken glass within the grounds, and there are reports of trails of blood on the ground.One local said it was very ldquobrazen of the louts to carry out these attacks at the school considering it is situated next door to the local police station.One parent added: ldquoThis is sickening. How can anyone think it is okay to do this "Someone knows who is responsible for this. Do the right thing and call it in to the police.Anyone with information should contact Police Scotland on .

title: mobile-recycling-service-arrives-borders
story: MOBILE recycling is set for ato the Borders.From next month a pilot, which allows for wood, electrical items, batteries and cooking oil as well as garden waste to be deposited, will be launched in Jedburgh.Andthe scheme is successful it will be rolled out to West Linton, Lauder, Coldstream and Newcastleton.The mobile recycling service is the latest effort by Scottish Borders Council for the region to become a landfill-free area.Councillor Gordon Edgar said: ldquoThe Borders public has helped save poundmillion a year on landfill tax thanks to their efforts in recycling.ldquoHowever, we still have around  per cent of waste in our general bins which could have been recycled."Not only does this have an impact on the local environment, this costs taxpayers over poundm a year which could be spent where.ldquoWe are always looking at ways to increase recycling in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThis mobile recycling service pilot scheme is our latest effort."The four-month mobile pilot will run from Sunday, September  to the Sunday before Christmas.A survey will carried out during the same period to gauge use and views ahead of a decision being made about a roll-out.Councillor Edgar added: "It is important to emphasise this is a pilot scheme, with the results of the pilot and survey to be considered fully before a final decision is made."The mobile recycling service will operate every Sunday in Lothian Park Car Parkbetween am and pm.middot

title: additional-needs-summer-camp-goes-bang
story: A SUMMER camp for children with additional needs has been hailed a huge success.The Borders Additional Needs Groupteamed up with Live Borders to host five days of fun and adventure at the Leader Valley School in Earlston.An inaugural camp was held last year over three days.But thanks to funding from Cash for Kids and Tescos Bags for Le, the  camp was extended - with more than  children enjoying the activities.And hopes are high that next years will be even bigger.Pauline Charles from BANG told us: ldquoThroughout my years of experience, I never expected the camp to be as good as this."Wersquove had  people through our doors and over  children."We have young carers, parent carers, siblings, grandparents, foster carers ndash itrsquos been overwhelming.ldquoLive Borders staff and BANG will evaluate this project, look at worked well, and what we can improve and start to redesign rsquos respite camp."Cash for Kids donated pound, towards the camp with pound, coming from Tescos.Plans are already taking shape for more camps throughout .Pauline added: "Parents have been asking for Easter, Summer and October camps."Irsquom working now with another charity to develop a bigger project next year.ldquoWe were very privileged to be able to use Leader Valley School and thatrsquos down to the relationship with SBC."The environment and the school lsquomakersquo the project. It provides a safe environment.All of the children were given the opportunity to take part in sporting activities, music and art projects.And it was also a chance for parents and carers to relax.Sports Development Manager from Live Borders, John McBay said: "Itrsquos been action-packed for the children, but above all, itrsquos been about fun and the children feeling very safe.ldquoThe parents are the critical bit - they often get missed in families where additional needs are required."We have to make sure that mum and dad have the opportunity just to chill out and relax.ldquoThe parents have all got together and been chatting and thought this has been a great outlet for them."They have all learnt from each other about some of the challenges they face at home and dferent copping strategies.ldquoWe would love to do this on a more regular basis and not just the holidays.

title: ban-boozed-up-bgh-driver

title: erin-designs-women-39-s-tour-scotland
story: ONE Peebles cycling fan has made her mark on the very first Womens Tour of Scotland.Some of the biggest names in womens cycling took part in the three-day event earlier this month.And the winner of the Best Young Rider was presented with a jersey designed by schoolgirl Erin Acherman.The -year-olds design, inspired by the hills of the Tweed Valley, was the pick of the peloton for race organisers.Erins prize included one of her own jerseys signed by all the the inaugural tour winners.Mum Judith told us: "Erin was inspired by the hills in the Tweed Valley and part of her prize was to go in the convoy car and hear all the race excitement from a prime spot."Despite dficult conditions for much of the three stages, the Womens Tour of Scotland has been hailed as a huge success.Riders from some of the worlds top teams set off from Dundee for Dunfermline on stage one.Day two of the race took the riders from Perth to Glasgow.And the finale involved a loop through Peeblesshire from the start and finish in Edinburgh.An estimated , cycling fans lined the  kilometre route over the three days.Winner of the race was -year-old American Leah Thomas from Team Bigla.And it was another Bigla team member, Nikola Noskovao won Erins Best Young Rider jersey.

title: last-ditch-plea-save-local-drama-group
story: A STRUGGLING local am-dram group is hoping help is at hand so the show can go on.Denholm Drama Group has been putting on performances for  years.But times are tough, as the group may now be forced to close, due to a lack of support.In recent years, the local drama enthusiasts have had to cut short or completely cancel their tours, due to not having enough members to produce performances.At the recent AGM an ultimatum was agreed... to either fold or make only last ditch attempt to rally support.Alan Dowler Smith from Denholm Drama Group said: "Many of our regular members have left, for one reason or another, and the Group has been struggling for some years to find plays that suit a small number of actors, particularly men."Additionally, our backstage members are not getting any younger, and the logistics of transporting a portable theatre around the countryside are becoming unsustainable."In the past, the group was somewhat a village staple.Exactly when it was formed is unclear, but it was certainly around in the s, when it performed in the old village hall.The groups first recorded performances began in  when pantomimes took place every year at the village primary school, often involving the school children.But in , a catastrophic fire put the groups future at risk.The societys assets were totally lost, and with no insurance cover, the future looked bleak.With generous donations from local organisations and grant aid from Scottish Borders Council, new equipment was purchased and the Group found a new role, touring local village and town halls, mostly performing one-act plays.Now,  years on, the group are struggling once again, and are on the verge of disbandment.Alan said: "It has been decided that as a last-ditched effort, a more robust recruitment drive will be carried out before September comes."However,insufficient interest is expressed, with deep regret the group will close down for ever, bringing a sad end to more than six decades of service to the local community."Anyone who wishes to register their interest in joining Denholm Drama Group should call Alan Bowler-Smith on .

title: innerleithen-music-festival-goes-swing
story: THE range of entertainment at last weekendrsquos Innerleithen Music Festival lsquosurpassed our high expectationsrsquo, according to Robin Dempsey from the coordinating committee.The core venues of Live  Local at the Vale Club and the St Ronanrsquos Hotel brought in the crowds for their continuous programme of fantastic bands.There were almost  performances between them, giving a stage for many local acts.But there was a wide iety on offer where, from outstanding classical music with The Taylor Family  Friends to colourful belly-dancing at the Union Club, taking in Gaelic singing, ukulele, border pipes and line-dancing on the way.Possibly the biggest audience over the weekend was at the Church of Scotland for Innerleithen born and bred Tommy Ashby who has achieved wide acclaim on the UK circuit.Meanwhile, at the late night Festival Club, in the middle of the many contributions from festival regulars, there was the unexpected pleasure of an impromptu demonstration of Breton folk dancing from a visiting French group.Robin told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoIt feels like the festival has completed a transition from its early years focussed on large scale concerts to a vibrant community based event."It was heart-warming to see so many locals and visitors, young and old, coming together to share their love of music, whether as performers or in the audience."

title: walking-festival-organisers-hail-volunteer-army
story: ORGANISERS of the forthcoming Scottish Borders Walking Festival are hailing the volunteers who have helped pull the packed programme of events together.Since the end of last year a small army of locals from Selkirk and the surrounding valleys have been mapping, plotting and organising.And they have been rewarded with a festival of walks and social events which are selling out fast.Sue Briggs, chair of the  Festival team, told us: ldquoItrsquos been amazing."People say they couldnrsquot run a festival without volunteers and in our case itrsquos  percent true."There are only four of us on the Festival team and the local community has really risen to the occasion and given us a huge amount of support."As well as leading the  planned walks, volunteers will also drive visitors to the drop-off points.Many other volunteers are also organising the social events which will be held throughout the week-long festival.And they will also be manning a pop-up cafe in the Victoria Halls to provide a warm welcome for the walkers.Among the many special offers of help which are being made, are the young people of Rowlands who are serving up ldquoHot and Tasty Comfort Food every weekday evening from pm to pm during the festival.InChorus community choir from Peebles will provide a ldquosinging send-off on the opening day - Saturday, September .Craigdon Mountain Sports are providing a boot clinic in the Victoria Halls on the opening weekend, and local choir Safety in Numbers are hosting a musical stroll around the Haining on the Sunday.Selkirk Community Shed are busily creating wooden walking figures for the entrances to the town.And many businesses have also offered support with raffle prizes.Sue added: "The Scottish Borders Walking Festival is very much a joint effort between the Festival team and the people of Selkirk and the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys."The Scottish Borders Walking Festival takes place in Selkirk and the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys from Saturday, September  to Saturday, September .Late availability tickets can be purchased from www.borderswalking

title: 14-year-old-found-major-search-peebles

title: eildon-eradicate-emissions-electric-vans
story: A BORDERS housing association is eradicating emissions with a new fleet of electric vehicles.Eildon introduced the new Nissan LEAF cars and Nissan E-NV vans earlier this month.And dedicated charging points have also been introduced at the social landlords headquarters in Selkirk.The vehicles have all been leased in partnership with Scottish Borders Council.John Duncan, director of Property Assets at Eildon commented: ldquoEildon is committed to ensuring we comply with the legislative requirements set for national targets, but we want to go beyond that, and positively promote best practice as a responsible and forward-looking organisation."Innovative new methods like this are key to what we are aiming to achieve, and this new electric fleet demonstrates our commitment.The new vehicles produce zero emissions, and with improvements in battery technology they can travel up to  miles on a single charge.The new charging points, which are live on Charge Place Scotland, are open to the public for vehicle charging.

title: strike-demo-planned-scottish-borders-council-hq
story: UP to  strikers and supporters are expected to hold a demonstration outside Scottish Borders Council headquarters on Thursday.A dispute between workers in the roads department and bosses at the local authority led to a vote being taken in June.A total of . percent of the Unite union members voted to take strike action over changes to their terms and conditions.The first day of industrial action will take place on Thursday.A spokesman for Unite told us: "Between  and  strikers and supporters are expected to assemble."The workers in the roads department have been treated with contempt and the latest efforts by the council to draft in contracted workers to cover workers taking action is disgraceful.ldquoInstead of positively engaging with the workers and Unite, the council seem intent on escalating the dispute."Unite will explore every legal avenue to challenge this aggressive action.ldquoUnite also believes that there is a strong legal case that workers are being offered unlawful financial inducements to break the existing collective bargaining agreements.The reasoning behind the dispute has been refuted by the local authority chief executive Tracey Logan.She told us: "Some of the allegations made by Unite about the planned strike by a small number of roads department staff on August  are absolutely unfounded and cannot be left unchallenged.ldquoThe council has not changed terms and conditions for this staff group, nor have we failed to consult the trade unions or the staff affected.ldquoIn fact, we discovered some months ago that a small number of staff in this section had been claiming a higher rate of overtime than they were entitled to under the agreed terms and conditions.ldquoThey were also claiming for time to travel to work when working weekend overtime, which again is not in line with the agreement in place.ldquoGiven that Unite agreed to these terms and conditions, I am surprised and disappointed that they now want some of their members to be given more favourable pay rates than others, and for this small group be able to claim additional allowances that their other members cannot."The strike is set to coincide with a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday morning between .am and .am.

title: galashiels-selkirk-benefit-south-scotland-funding-boost
story: GALASHIELS and Selkirk are both set to benefit from the latest round of South of Scotland Economic Partnership funding.Almost pound, has been awarded to Philiphaugh Estate to improve its salmon viewing centre, establish a Golden Eagle visitor centre and expand the Waterwheel Cafe.And Energise Galashiels have been granted more than pound, to help enhance the town centre ahead of the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre opening.A total of pound,, was announced by Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing to help support five projects across the region.On his visit to Philiphaugh, he said: "The Scottish Government, working with the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, is determined to help the South of Scotland to realise its full economic potential."Wersquore doing that by targeted investments in projects which we believe will act as the catalysts for creating new businesses, providing vital skills, and making the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe work of the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, the establishment of a new enterprise body for the region, and the pound million we are investing in the Borderlands inclusive Growth Deal, underline our commitment to continuing to deliver for the South of Scotland and its people.Also included in the funding announcement was pound, for Community Enterprise Support.The pilot project aims to increase the number of financially sustainable community enterprises across both the Borders and Dumfries and Galloway.Initial target areas for the programme, which will build business and financial skills, are Galashiels, Jedburgh, Hawick, Eyemouth  East Berwickshire, Stranraer, Langholm, Upper Nithsdale and Dumfries.An already successful programme which is being run in Dumfries and Galloway is being expanded into the Borders with the help of almost pound, of funding.Growing Rural Skills will build on the success of a recent dairy sector pilot and broaden the sectors supported to include forestry.And concluding this weeks funding announcement was almost pound, going to the Eyemouth-based social enterprise ReTweed, which helps women start and grow their own business within the creative industries sector.South of Scotland Economic Partnership Chair, Professor Russel Griggs, said: "This major funding announcement is fantastic news for the South of Scotland."From wildle to town centre regeneration, these five projects will help support and deliver long-term social and economic benefits to communities in the Scottish Borders and Dumfries  Galloway by creating new businesses, providing vital skills and making the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe economy of the south of Scotland will benefit greatly from this new impetus to stimulate growth
