title: first-look-inside-glasgows-largest-office-block
story: HFD Property Group, which earlier this year secured an pound.m development loan through the Bank of Scotland for the project, has created a fly-through vision of its striking newbuilding from the ground up.That funding package providedthe business with the development capital to complete the , sq ft commercial accommodation, which is the final part of its Bothwell Exchange office campus in Glasgow.: Scotlands first rooftop running track set for Glasgow office developmentOnce complete,  Bothwell Street will be the largest multi-occupancy office building in the city.It has already secured tenants, with Clydesdale Banks CYBG signing a -year lease for over , sq ft. HFDrsquos managed office ision will also lease over , sq ft of the development.:Dark cloud above our heads in form of Brexit after spectacular year in commercial propertyIt is also the first development in Scotland to be accredited with a Platinum WiredScore Certication.Stephen Lewis, managing director at HFD Property Group, said: ldquoGlasgow thriving business community needs new, quality office space to support its growth, help attract talent and new occupiers to the city."

title: green-msp-retire-next-holyrood-election
story: Highlands and Islands MSP John Finnie has announced he will step down at the next election after a decade in the parliament.It comes as his party, which currently has six MSPs, starts selecting candidates for .Mr Finnie, , is behind the proposed ban on smacking, which began as a private memberrsquos bill that went on to receive Scottish Government support.In the wake of this yearrsquos budget deal between the SNP and Greens, Mr Finnie has also been spearheading the proposed workplace parking levy, or parking tax.The former police officer was the first Green elected in the Highlands and Islands, winning on the list system in  and again in .He is one half of the only father and child double act at parliament - his daughter Ruth Maguire is the SNP MSP for Cunninghame South.He said: ldquoIt is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.ldquoIrsquove been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.ldquoThroughout my time in Parliament, Irsquove put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.ldquoAt this time, Irsquom focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Memberrsquos Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.ldquoThe Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. I know there are others who can ensure they are promoted, and delivered, for my home, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Meanwhile, I look forward to having more time to spend with my family.

title: sturgeon-criticised-visiting-shetland-39-s-election
story: With voters going to the polls on Thursday in a two-horse race between the LibDems and SNP, Ms Sturgeon has been in the seat three times since July .However it has emerged she has only been in the constituency once since becoming First Minister in , and that was also for an election.Ms Sturgeon visited an SNP campaign hub in April  ahead of the Holyrood poll.There is only one mention of Shetland on her First Ministers website, and that was a reference to an energy storage project in .:Sturgeon links uphill Shetland byelection to independenceMs Sturgeons predecessor, Alex Salmond, did visit Shetland as First Minister, holding a meeting of the summer cabinet there in July .Scottish LibDem candidate Beatrice Wishart said: "The First Minister is oblivious to the islands when shersquos in Edinburgh. Perhaps making the journey to Shetland herself will have made her realise just what a problem expensive and under-resourced transport links are."Shetlands not just for elections."Shetland is the safest seat in Scotland on paper, with former LibDem leader Tavish Scott winning it for a fth time in  with a . point lead over the SNP.However Mr Scott quit politics to work for Scottish Rugby in June, and the SNP have thrown money and manpower at the Shetland seat in the hope of a shock upset.SNP hopeful Tom Wills is challenging the LibDem favourite.The Scottish Conservatives accused the SNP leader of ldquoonly caring about Shetland when there are votes to be won.:Shetland byelection turns ugly as SNP graffiti sprayed on war memorialTory candidate Brydon Goodland said: ldquoThe First Minister has barely been out of Shetland during this by-election campaign.ldquoWe have been graced with three visits, but these records show that Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP only care about Shetland when there are votes to be won.ldquoThe people of Shetland need an MSP and a party that will stand up for this area all year round, not just when there is a parliamentary seat at stake.Tory Highlands  Islands MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston added: ldquoThese figures sum up the SNPrsquos approach to this by-election in a nutshell.ldquoNicola Sturgeon is never normally seen in these parts, but now there is an election on the line, the First Minister and party activists are flooding into Shetland.ldquoPeople will see through this charade and understand that they need a representative at parliament that wonrsquot be a fair weather friend, but a champion for this area every day.RESD MORE:Tom Gordon: SNP could win in Shetland, but pay for it at HolyroodThe SNP said Tory leader Ruth Davidson appeared not to have been to Shetland since .SNP MEP Christian Allard said: ldquoThe Tories have made themselves look ridiculous - not only are they highlighting how often the First Minister has visited Shetland in this campaign, they are also raising the question of why Ruth Davidson hasnrsquot bothered, as she continues to stay in hiding amid her partyrsquos Brexit shambles.

title: homes-deal-struck-sir-toms-1bn-new-town
story: Winchburgh Developments Limitedannounced that a new contract has been agreed with Robertson Homes to sell land to the housebuilder for  new four, five and six-bedroom homes.It takes the total number of homes now contracted to be built in the second phase of the Winchburgh masterplan to . The overall pound billion, ,-home development will encircle the village of Winchburgh, seven miles from Edinburgh Airport.Negotiations are also under way with additional developers to conclude agreements which will account for about half of the phase two housing programme, scheduled to deliver a total of , new homes by .WATCH:First look: Inside Glasgows largest office blockBuilding work is due to begin imminently, with the first Robertson homes expected to be released for sale early next year.John Hamilton, WDL chief executive, said: ldquoThe contract with Robertson is an important step towards delivering the , new homes we will complete in the second phase of residential building at Winchburgh.ldquoThe masterplan for Winchburgh is very quickly gaining pace.ldquoAs well as the  plots now contracted, wersquore in negotiations to conclude agreements for more than  per cent of the phase two housing programme.ldquoWest Lothian Council is in consultation to build three new schools during phase two and work is already under way on the -acre Auldcathie District Park. We have also recently announced a new contract with Scottish Canals to build a new marina at the centre of the town, making Winchburgh an extremely attractive option for people looking for a new property.:Sir Tom Hunter hails progress made with West Lothian new townTony Rankin, land director at Robertson Homes said: ldquoFurther to our success with ourdevelopment in Mid Calder, we are excited to be back in West Lothian delivering  houses from our new Artistry luxury range in Winchburgh.ldquoWinchburgh is such a beautul rural location and with a mature tree belt on one side and rolling countryside views on the other, combined with the easy commuting distance to Edinburgh it is the perfect setting for our executive family homes.Winchburgh is described as one of the largest and most exciting place-making projects currently under way in the UK delivering new homes, improved transport links, employment opportunities, state-of-the-art schools and stunning new outdoor spaces to the historic town.:Work begins on new poundm park in West LothianSpanning  hectares, the development will add to the  homes completed in phase one.When complete the masterplan will deliver at least , homes, including  affordable homes of which  will be for social rent, with WDL responsible for delivering the overall masterplan.Sir Toms West Coast Capital said earlier that it is making a multi-million pound investment in coming decades in the Winchburgh.He bought into the project in  and West Coasts confidence in the Winchburgh plan has increasedafter the company won backing for the project from one of the UKs biggest insurers and struck key agreements with the Scottish Government and West Lothian Council to support work on the related infrastructure.His firm has formed a joint venture with Cala Homes to invest in the development and delivery of the new town.

title: medical-dental-staff-scotland-win-2-5-pay-rise
story: The boost - above the rate of inflation - will be included in next months salaries, with payments backdated to April  to follow "as soon as practical".Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said the increase will help NHS Scotland "remain an attractive employment option" for those staff.She said: "Its the continued hard work and dedication of staff which makes our NHS the treasured institution it is and this uplt demonstrates that we fully value all our staff and the important contribution they make."Its crucial we continue to not only recruit and build our future NHS workforce, but also retain expertise."She added: "This announcement means junior doctors working on typical rotas in Scotland can be up to pound, a year better off than their English equivalents, and our specialty doctors, associate specialist doctors and consultants will remain the best paid in the UK."This will help ensure that NHS Scotland remains an attractive employment option for medical and dental staff."Last month, Chancellor Philip Hammond announced a .% pay increase for hospital doctors and dentists in England, in line with the recommendation by the independent pay review body for these sectors.Doctors organisation BMA Scotland had urged the Scottish Government to award consultants a pay increase in line with this deal, warning that a lower award would be the "last straw" for the senior doctors and would hit NHS services.BMA Scotland chairman Lewis Morrison said the announcement is "hopefully a first step" to addressing the impact of "years of real-term cuts" in doctors pay.He said: "The fact that the Scottish Government has listened to the BMA and this year broken with public-sector pay policy and met the Review Body on Doctors and Dentists Remunerations general pay uplt recommendation of .% for all doctors demonstrates greater and encouraging recognition of their huge contribution to frontline care."He criticised ministers for failing to listen to the pay bodys call for an additional % for some specially-trained doctors.Mr Morrison added: "We regard a .% uplt as just a reasonable start and certainly not a cause for celebration."It is only just higher than the CPI measure of inflation and measured against RPI - which is currently at .% - it remains a real-terms pay cut."A spokesman for the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh said: "At a time when NHS doctors are facing growing pressure on their professional time, it is vital that they are made to feel valued."The backdated pay award is a very welcome way of doing that. But we would like the Scottish Government to go further."Introducing protected time for doctors to teach and research, as well as better rest facilities and input into rota design, would be positive ways to show doctors that they are truly valued."

title: scotlands-first-community-owned-school-officially-opened
story: Strontian Primary School, on the Ardnamurchan peninsula in the Highlands, was built after the community of around  people rejected Highland Councils plans to improve their old primary school building.Community members raised around pound, towards the project, with cash coming from the community-owned hydro scheme as well as local donations.The school building was jointly funded by a commercial loan from Triodos Bank, a payment for tenants works from Highland Council, a community share offer which raised more than pound,, and pound, in grants from the Scottish Land Fund and Foundation Scotland.Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: "It gives me great pleasure to open the first school in Scotland to be developed through a community ownership model."The innovative work of parents and the wider Strontian community, alongside construction companies and Highland Council, has given local young people a fit-for-purpose school they can be proud of for years to come."Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said: "The opening of a new school is an exciting day for any community, but this is even more special because it is the community who built it."I know that it has not been easy or pain-free but this is an incredible day for Strontian and the surrounding areas. The new school is a great facility for the young people of the peninsula."I am delighted that the Deputy First Minister of Scotland came to formally open the school, in recognition that this is not just an important day for the Highlands but indeed for all of Scotland."Jamie McIntyre, chairman of Strontian Community School Building Ltd, said the community is "delighted" with the new school and thanked all those who made it possible.He added: "The end result exceeds our expectations and is a real asset for our community which will help retain and attract young families."It has been a challenging undertaking for our community. Hopefully our experience will make it easier for other communities to progress similar projects of their own."

title: great-british-bake-off-series-10-episode-one
story: The Great British Bake OffChannel  ****WE donrsquot have trains that run on time and World Cup qualication remains a distant memory, butthere is ever a contest for kitchen mishaps,Scotlandis in with a shout.That was one takeaway from The Great British Bake Off, which began its tenth season last night. Can it only be two years ago when it seemed the world was about to end because Bake Off had left BBC, the dependable Victoria Sponge of broadcasting, for those fondant fancies at Channel   And here we are again, watching folk baking cakes while the Amazon burns.Most of the bakerrsquos dozen of contestants were tender in years, with one chap so young his voice broke during the showstopper round. At the other end of the age spectrum was Phil, , an HGV driver, and in the middle stood a vet, a student, a fashion designer, a teacher, and a motley crew of other well-scrubbed, chirpy types. At this stage in the game their characters remain an eggy blur.One standout was the representative for Scotland, Michael,  . Michael was born in Newcastle and lives in Stratford-upon-Avon where he is a theatre manager fitness instructor. He considers himself Scottish because the family moved to Sconewhen he was seven and he studied in Edinburgh. Welcome aboard, mate.: GBBO shows no sign of turning into stodgeBefore we got to the first challenge, making a fruitcake, judges Paul Hollywood and Prue Leith, and presenters Sandi Toksvig and Noel Fielding, did the now traditional opening skit. They opted for the Wizard of Oz, which involved Noel, as Dorothy, wearing a gingham dress. Sandi asked, ldquoIs it weird I fancy you now  Paul chipped in: ldquoSo do I. Paul, as you may have read in the papers, is currently going through a messy orce and a split from his younger lover. He is bearing up remarkably well. Must be all that sugar.Michael, in honour of his Scottish Indian heritage, was making a ldquoCup of Chai fruitcake. His mum had texted him at am that day to tell him to ldquoBe calm, be slow, and be confident. Wise words, to which every other mother, having seen Michael chop fruit with giddy abandon, added: ldquoAND BE CAREFUL WITH THAT BLOODY KNIFE! Sure enough, he cut himself. His fingers were already covered in plasters. ldquoThis has to be the last one, he sighed, ldquoI donrsquot have any left. Whether he was talking about fingers or plasters it was not clear. By episode three we can expect a nationwide call for blood donors.On we cantered to the technical challenge, angel cake slices, which had to be made according to Pruersquos -stage recipe. If your instinct on hearing the phrase ldquo-stage recipe is to drive to the nearest petrol station for a Battenberg, applying to take part in Bake Off probably isnrsquot for you.: The Bake Off effectIn keeping with the showrsquos naughty but nice traditions there were several servings of double entendre with whipped filth on top, as when Paul thought one contestant was going to make a furry garden rather than a fairy one for her showstopper birthday cake. ldquoHow big is your furry garden  he giggled. Steady on, fella, yoursquore in enough hot water.There were some calamities, but only minor ones like forgetting to switch a timer on. We hope for bigger, better, worse, in the nine weeks to come. As for who was named star baker and who was given their marching orders I cannot oblige, because TV reviewers are not trusted with the final seconds. Asanyone would be daft enough to give the game away, eh Prue  Whoever triumphed, Irsquoll bet victory was sweet.

title: bbc-take-alexa-launch-voice-assistant
story: The new system, called Beeb, will be built into the BBCrsquos website and iPlayer on smart TVs, but will not be a standalone device such as Amazon Echo or Google Home.It will allow users to find their favourite programmes and use the BBCrsquos online services. The software will also be made available to manufacturers who want to incorporate it in their products.The BBC has pledged to make sure the system understands regional accents by asking office staff around the UK to record their voices to ldquotrain the software.US-developed voice assistants famously do not cope well with regional accents, with videos of people getting into comical arguments with smart assistants not understanding their accents going viral online.A study also found . per cent of Scots said they were frustrated when speaking to systems such as Alexa and Siri.People are also likely to drop their accentsaltogether when speaking to systems such as Alexa or Siri for fear of not being understood, according to a survey conducted in Newcastle.The BBCrsquos voice assistant will be activatedby saying the word ldquoBeeb, but some analysts are sceptical over the reliability of the word.Ben Wood, from CCS Insight, told the BBC:ldquoTypically, voice assistants use a multi-syllable word or phrase such as Alexa or Hey Google to ensure accurate identication. I fear Beeb might end up being unreliable.The BBC replied the word worked well during research, but it was not a final decision.Beeb is developed by the BBCrsquos own team, so it will not present users with the broad range of services offered by Alexa or Siri, which are made by major technology companies. Mr Wood told the BBC it would be dficult for the public broadcaster to compete with the tech giants.Voice assistants have become a common feature in British homes, as one-fth of UK households now own a smart speaker.Beyond offering users from around the UK the ability to use a voice assistant without the need to drop their accent, Beeb is intended to give the BBC more independence, in particular to collect userrsquos data. The BBC will withdraw its radio stations from the popular InTune app, which is used by Alexa, after Amazon refused to share user data with the Corporation.The BBC told : ldquoWith an assistant of its own, the BBC will have the freedom toexperiment with new programmes, features and experiences without someone rsquos permission to build it in a certain way. It will also allow the BBC to be much more ambitious in the content and features that listeners can enjoy.The BBC said it is also aware of usersrsquo concerns with commercial voice assistants and their use of their data.The broadcaster said: ldquoPeople know and trust the BBC, so it will use its role as public service innovator in technology to ensure everyone ndash not just thetech-elite ndash can benefit from accessing content and new experiences in this new way.In the UK, an estimated . million Britons use a smart speaker at least once a month, or theequivalent of .% of internet users, according to data by emarketer. Amazon currently beats competitors as the biggest smart speaker providerin Britain, with a market share of .%. Googlehas .%.Globally, Amazon dominates the smart speaker market with .% market share in the secondquarter of , according to a report by Canalys. Newcomer Chinese-owned Baidu comes second at .%, and Google third at .%.Scots facing issues with voice recognition have been a comedy topic for years. In , a clip in sketch show Burnistoun showing two Scots unsuccessfully trying to talk to an elevator, became an internet favourite. Two years ago, the firstGlaswegian voice assistant, ldquoSenga, appeared in show Gted and Gallus on BBC Scotland.

title: citizen-science-activists-target-salmon-farms
story: Environmental and animal welfare groups are to carry out their own tests on the public waters around salmon farms, as they call for the industry to address fears over disease and animal welfare issues.The peaceful protest follows a,-name petition calling onthe Scottish Government to make emergency inspections of salmon farms.Don Stanord, director of environmental campaign group Scottish Salmon Watch, which is coordinating a nationwide citizen science action plan at farms around the Scottish coast, said: ldquoThe Oban area will be the first one this weekend. We will leave Dunstaffnage Marina, outside Oban, with people swimming and in kayaks and we will be sampling effluent across salmon farm cages.ldquoWe will sample the effluent around salmon farms and conduct some citizen science.He claimed: ldquoOver  per cent of farmed salmon tested by the Scottish Government have got a virus and will have all kinds of toxic waste.ldquoOne-fth to one-quarter of all farmed salmon are dying every year. If this was happening on land there would be outrage. Itrsquos a case of out of sight, outof mind.Mr Stanord says the police and salmon farm companies have been notied that activists will begin their plan by circling salmon feedlots around Norwegian owned Mowi and Scottish Sea Farms at their sites in the Firth of Lorn, Sound of Jura and Loch Linnhe.Protesters will wear fancy dress, with outfits including a lobster in a gas mask, a salmon, a harbour porpoise in ear defenders and a seal in bullet proof vest being used to highlight their cause.Sondhya Gupta, of campaign group SumofUs, said: ldquoTherersquos a rising tide of pubic opposition to Scottish salmon farmsrsquo dirty business.ldquoScottish salmon should be the pride of Scotland ndash not a shameful secret branded sustainable while fish live in filthy conditions, unfit for any animal.ldquoThis year, over , SumofUs members called for the Scottish Government to force emergency inspections of salmon farms.ldquoWhile [there is a] delay, wersquore stepping in ndash but as some point regulators need to do their own job.Animal Concern group spokesman John Robins said it was time for people to reclaim the seas from floating fish farms, which are polluting the nationrsquos coastal waters, destroying wildle and turning the king of fish into the equivalent of battery hens.He claimed: ldquoSalmon farming is unsustainable, incredibly cruel and very damaging for the marine environment.ldquoThe Scottish Government must take the lead from protesters and act now to stop salmon farmers destroying our coastal ecosystem.Aquaculture has become crucial to Scotland in helping to sustain economic growth in rural and coastal communities, particularly in the north and west.It is a erse sector that takes in the farming of both finfish ndash dominated by the production of Atlantic salmon ndash and shellfish species, such as mussels and Pacic oysters.The Scottish Government supporteda working group that launched the strategy to boost the value of Scottish aquaculture from pound. billion in  to pound.bn by .There was also a desire to see the number of jobs double to , over the same period.But those ambitions have taken a hit with growing concerns over fish welfare standards.At the centre of the debate is salmonndashthe largest component of the Scottish aquaculture industry, with about , tonnes produced on farmseach year.It is Scotlandrsquos single biggest food export and worth pound million.The industry says that  per cent of Scottish salmon are certied to the RSPCA Farm Assured scheme ndash a higher percentage than any other UK farming sector.But last year, the salmon farming industry came under fire for ldquoshocking levels of fish deaths as it emerged they hit record levels due to diseases and parasites.Sea lice, which have been a major problem for the farmed salmon industry, feed on the skin and blood of salmon, and can weaken the health of a fish and stunt its growth.There is further concern about non-native rainbow trout escaping from farm cages with the ability to out compete with native species and preying on juvenile populations.While the sector spends around pound million per year in research and more than poundm in new equipment and techniques to understand and manage health and environmental problems, it emerged in April levels of wild salmon in Scotland are at their lowest since records began.At the end of , the last Scottish wild salmon netting station closed because there were so few fish to catch. As a result, Scottish wild salmon is now off the menu.Following the Saturday and Sunday protests around Oban, representativesof Salmon Watch will visit the Scottish Parliament and Marine Scotland on Monday.Hamish Macdonell, director of strategic engagement for the Scottish Salmon Producersrsquo Organisation said: ldquoUnauthorised visits to fish farms place employees and the animals they carefor at risk.ldquoThey also pose serious hazards to those entering the farms without permission.ldquoAs a result, any visit must be undertaken in accordance with the strict safety and biosecurity measures in place on each farm and take place only with the express permission of the farm manager.ldquoSalmon farmers ask that people remain a safe distance away from farms and other facilities, for the safety of all involved and to protect the health and welfare of thelivestock.

title: jim-gallagher-britain-needs-new-type-progressive-federalism
story: Prof Gallagher was Whitehallrsquos most senior civil servant concerned with devolution, working as the Director-General for Devolution in the Cabinet Office, the No  Policy Unit and Ministry of Justice.He retired in June  and is now an academic heavily involved in the Scottish constitutional question and a director in the commercial and charitable sectors.In , he was appointed Visiting Professor of Government at Glasgow University and has also been a Visiting Professor in the Centre for Public and Corporate Ethics at Glasgow Caledonian University.Since , he has been a research fellow at Nuffield College in Oxford. He is co-author of England and the Union, How and Why to Answer the West Lothian Question and of Scotlandrsquos Choices, the Referendum and What Happens Afterwards.Todays world is suddenly all about nationalisms, some of them very disagreeable, as in Hungary or the US, others very disruptive, like Brexit or, potentially, Scottish nationalism. This poses a problem for many on the left who think politics isnt about achieving national sovereignty, but promoting social justice. They struggle to deal with it, and find a coherent vision of how to reconcile peoples need for identity and the demands of economic opportunity and social justice.Brexit has upset the UKrsquos constitutional applecart, and this English nationalist project has encouraged Scottish nationalism. Both projects seek to break up multinational unions in the name of sovereignty. Brexit has already split the UK down the middle, and similar vote in some future Scottish referendum would create a fissure in Scottish society that would last generations. We need something better.Whatever happens with Brexit, there is an alternative for the UK. The risks to economic opportunity and social justice presented by independence stem not from acknowledging Scottish identity, nor from increasing Scottish autonomy, but from breaking the economic and social bonds of the United Kingdom. Its domestic market is vital for Scotlands economy, and sharing resources across the UK supports social justice in Scotland through welfare and public spending programmes, as we saw again last week the latest GERS figures.We do not have to lose these benefits in order to gain more autonomy. Instead, Scotland, and the rest of the UK, should move to a more federal system. The structures of federalism, which means dferent levels of government each with their own responsibilities, can support dferent social models, but I argue for a progressive form of federalism, one designed to create the maximum scope for social justice in each part of the country. Here is what it would mean for Scotland.First of all, it implies a change of mindset in the whole UK, from the worn-out notions of parliamentary sovereignty which drive so much of our overcentralised government, especially in England, to an understanding that the UK really is a multinational state, a voluntary association of nations which come together to preserve their identities and promote their shared interests. That implies a better form of entrenchment for devolution in the UK constitution. Given the circumstances of Brexit, it means entrenching wider powers too.More important, perhaps, it implies a design which embeds the purpose of social justice in the territorial constitution. The federal UK parliament and government should be responsible for providing a guaranteed level of welfare and public service provision across the whole territory, irrespective of whether local taxable resources are big enough to support it, much as today.But government in the devolved nations should have the capacity to increase this from their own resourcesthey think it necessary. Thatrsquos an each-way bet for social justice.Wersquore already close to that for Scotland today. Not only is the Scottish Parliament responsible for most major public services, but it can supplement any welfare benefit it thinks unjustly small. It has the money too: not only is the devolved budget about  per cent per head higher than English levels, Holyrood has wide tax powers too.A UK which followed these principles would make a similar offer to the dferent regions of England. Many of those who voted Leave in the European referendum were expressing a beef with London, not Brussels: thats where they need to take back control from.Those obsessed with sovereignty and identity see nationalism as an end in itself. History tells us this is a dangerous road. But those who want to promote social justice and co-operation between dferent peoples cannot ignore the human need for acknowledgement of their identity. For them the right approach is a model of progressive federalism, empowering the UKrsquos nations and regions in a way which gives each level of government the power to promote a just society.This will be one of the themes explored by the new Think Tank Our Scottish Future being launched with an address by former PM Gordon Brown in Edinburgh this week.

title: andrew-mckie-no-chance-stopping-no-deal-brexit
story: You donrsquot ndash whether you think Parliament is ignoring the original vote, or failing to stop an impending catastrophe ndash get a say. But Mr Corbyn, the keenest subscriber to the view that hersquos best suited to the job, was yesterday sounding out other Westminster opposition leaders. Alas, since theyrsquod settle for anyone, except Mr Corbyn, they united instead on seeking a legislative route to rule out a no-deal Brexit."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jeremy Corbyn agrees to prioritise cross-party legislation to stop no-deal Brexit","description": "Cross-party talks led by Labours Jeremy Corbyn have resulted in a co-ordinated effort to thwart Boris Johnsons plans for a no-deal Brexit.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs hzIHip-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests hzIHip.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Iain Macwhirter: Gordon Browns caring sharing Union is dead. Brexit has killed itUnsurprisingly, because they paint an exit with no deal as a national disaster along the lines of the Black Death or Scotlandrsquos  World Cup campaign. Yet even those people, who previously promised to implement the referendum result, thenstood on a manesto promising to implement the result, then, by one of the biggest Commons vote ever, voted to implement Article , specying ldquono deal as the default, balked at putting Mr Corbyn in power as the price of stopping any hard exit.Itrsquos dficult to see how legislation guarantees the prevention of no deal, though. Itrsquos an illogical position, when no deal is the default, and when any restrictions wouldnrsquot be binding on the PM, nor even necessarily within his gt .It is, however, no more bonkers than the Brexit Partyrsquos insistence that only a no deal Brexit is real Brexit ndash a stance no doubt inspired by government failure to deliver, but one that no one was advocating three years ago.Mr Corbyn, unlike the other party leaders, mentioned the continued possibility of a vote of no confidence. As Leader of the Opposition, hersquos best-placed to table one, but that is the extent of his advantage. Assumingit were won, the Labour leader would then have to demonstrate he had the necessary support to form a government, which means about  votes: ie, persuading some  non-Labour MPs to vote for him.The prospect of Tories, even those practically demented by the idea of no deal, backing that is nil. The Lib Dems have ruled it out. It would be a huge strategic error for the SNP. And thatrsquos before you take into consideration the fact that there could well be about  of Mr Corbynrsquos own MPs who wouldnrsquot vote for it.Mr Corbyn, despite not banging on about it in his meeting, is still apparently insisting that a vote would mean him becoming prime minister .I think a GNU would be undemocratic, undesirable and unlikely. But in a fantasy world where the proposed interim PM were Ken Clarke, or Harriet Harman, itrsquos just about possible. But you would need a vote of no confidence first. So the person best placed to bring it about is Jeremy Corbyn, and the biggest obstacle to it happening is Jeremy Corbyn.Small wonder the other leaders preferred to make it a last resort, trying instead to rule out no deal by legislation. The problem is that you canrsquot, with absolute certainty, for both practical and political reasons. Practically, because MPs have to vote for something, anything  to avoid what is otherwise the default position, and so far they canrsquot agree on what that would be. Eventhey could, therersquos no guarantee itrsquos anything thatrsquos on offer.:Will SNP efforts to unseat Lib Dems be enough for Shetland by-election victoryAnd while the no deal absolutists are as deluded as the revoke extremists, there are potential deals ndash and the one negotiated by Theresa May is one ndash clearly even worse than no deal. Thatrsquos why MPs voted it down three times.Politically, this approach is tricky because, while Boris Johnson says he would still rather have a deal, he is totally committed to exit by October . Just as his mind wonrsquot be changed by a vote saying MPs wonrsquot accept no deal, nor will such a vote magic away the fact that itrsquos the legal default. His opponents would also have to commit to some positive course of action to replace it: either the blatantly anti-democratic nuclear option of outright revocation, or acceptance of some deal that is actually on offer at the time. Or an election.By contrast, the PM has nothing to lose by calling an election. Therersquos a sporting chance he could win itwersquove left the EU, or would do so during the campaign, or at oncehe won. Therersquos the near-certainty that the Brexit Party would prevent him winninghe were to show the slightest sign of backing down on the date.This is now a game of chicken where everyone ndash Johnson, Corbyn, Remainers, Brexit absolutists, and the EU ndash believes that their only chance of getting what they want is not to blink. The rest of us can only close our eyes and cross our fingers

title: teens-not-ones-misbehave-gigs
story: A couple of months ago, in the first throes of summer, we were quick to bemoan the army of neon-clad adolescents who descended on Glasgowrsquos TRNSMT festival, leaving a trail of glitter behind them. Loud  Yes. Using empty Lucozade bottles to disguise a half a litre of Mad Dog  Almost definitely. But, the way social media sharpened its pitchforks, you would have thought heart-shaped sunglasses were a calling card for the eventual downfall of society.All that fuss is why I find it is pertinent to point out that, after several weeks of attending massive outdoor concerts, itrsquos not young lsquouns who are the problem.It wasnrsquot a teenager who jabbed me in the back repeatedly with a selfie stick, and the woman who obnoxiously heckled Dave Grohl throughout the Foo Fighterrsquos recent Bellahouston Park gig certainly wasnrsquot born in the noughties. See also: the greying gentleman who downed a pint only to bring it back up all over the poor person in frontof him.The younger lot  They smiled, laughed and sang along, offering a cheerful ldquosorry pal whenever an overzealous dance move hit someone next to them.Rather than declaring a case of Teenagers versus the Middle Aged, I think it is important to ask: is this actually annoying, or am I just getting a bit old  For me ndash someone who is young enough to happily elbow my way to the front of a gig but old enough that my lower back will feel the effects of it the next day ndash it is a bit of both.During my recent gig adventures, I found my eyes rolling at a younger couple who spent the majority of The Curersquos two-and-a-half hour set with their tongues in each otherrsquos mouths. Then I sheepishly remembered that, only one decade earlier, I had been guilty of doing exactly the same thing. By my own admission, I am an ageing hypocrite with a short memory.Still, it remains my observation that those who claim to be older and wiser are often drunker and sloppier, as anyone forced to endure public transport the last time Take That played Glasgow will attest. The finger of blame may often be pointed at teenagers because itrsquos easy but the real anti-social behaviour is hardly limited to those under the age of .As far as Irsquom concerned, the kids are alright. Not so convinced about the parents.

title: freshwater-pearls-fund-scottish-river
story: The successfully-breeding population was found in one of the tributaries of the River Spey in an area of native woodland by Kieran Leigh-Moy while he was interning with Scottish Natural Heritage .Freshwater pearl mussels can live up to  years old, but the species is critically endangered as populations across Europe have not been breeding successfully for several decades.But the new colony found on Speyside appears in rude health, with juvenile mussels spotted among the adult mussel beds.Kieran Leigh-Moy has been working on a project to understand why the declining populations of freshwater pearl mussels in the river were not breeding and locate sites where they could be reintroduced to help their recovery.While developing a method for identying the most suitable locations, he came across a previously unknown population which, signicantly, contained juveniles.One of the mussels found by MrLeigh-MoyFreshwater pearl mussels can live up to  years old, but the species is critically endangered as a large proportion of the populations across Europe have not been successfully breeding for several decades.Mr Leigh-Moy, who was working on a project to develop a method for identying suitable locations for pearl mussel beds, said: ldquoIrsquod already identied this river as potentially having good quality habitat, so was visiting the site to conduct more in-depth surveys to seeit would be a suitable site for a reintroduction, but was stunned to find juvenile freshwater pearl mussels already there.:Mussels lsquostressedrsquo by under sea noise, Scottish research suggestsldquoItrsquos really rare to find a new population of these mussels, and especially one that is breeding successfully, so it was a really exciting moment.ldquoWhatrsquos particularly signicant is that the juvenile mussels found were many miles away from the nearest known breeding population and thatrsquos good news because it could help to prevent further range contraction of the species.It is hoped the approach developed by Mr Leigh-Moycan be used to help direct conservation efforts and find good habitat for freshwater pearl mussels at other locations, as well as mitigate the shrinking range of the species in the river.Keiran Leigh-MoyThe pearl mussel is a strong indicator of good environmental conditions and their recovery in this part of the catchment is likely testament to sensitive land management in the area.SNH and Forestry and Land Scotland are working to promote this kind of land management, which includes reducing pollution and establishing riverside woodlands, through their support of the Spey Catchment Initiative.Giles Brockman, from Forestry and Land Scotland, said: ldquoThis is really exciting news.ldquoForest management is not just about trees and this is a strong indication that actions to protect water courses are effective and can help to sustain and nurture wildle and rare species.:New plea for Scotlands at-risk pearl mussel as bid to stop illegal fishing falters#This type of land management will help allow rivers, and iconic species like pearl mussels, to cope with increased temperatures resulting from climate change. This is especially important for freshwater pearl mussels, which are a species that is particularly sensitive to any changes in climate.SNH has also been promoting sensitive land management more widely through our work to protect freshwater pearl mussels in the Pearls in Peril LIFE project that sought to save and restore populations in  rivers across Scotland, England and Wales.Through its pound. million Bioersity Challenge Fund, SNH is supporting a number of projects to enhance key freshwater pearl mussel populations across Scotland.Together with the Scottish Government the organisation is also managing a project starting this month to identy the sources of fine sediments in three key pearl mussel catchments - including the River Spey.:Chefrsquos quest for lsquoclabby dhursquo finally yields a taste from familyrsquos past#APEM and the University of Plymouth have been appointed to conduct state-of-the-art ldquosediment fingerprintingwhere there is evidence that important mussel populations are being adversely impacted by fine sediment inputs."This will be the first step in reducing the impact of fine sediments on freshwater pearl mussels, which is identied as among the primary drivers of the decline of this species across Europe.

title: highlands and islands msp to retire at next election
story: Highlands and Islands Green MSP John Finnie has announced that he will retire at the next Scottish Parliamentary election.The Scottish Greens have begun selecting candidates for the election in  and Mr Finnie, who was first elected to represent the Highlands and Islands in  and subsequently re-elected in , has indicated that he will not seek a further term.Speaking of his decision, which he announced earlier today, Mr Finnie said: â€œIt is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.â€œIâ€™ve been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.â€œThroughout my time in Parliament, Iâ€™ve put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.â€œAt this time, Iâ€™m focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Memberâ€™s Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.â€œThe Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. I know there are others who can ensure they are promoted, and delivered, for my home, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Meanwhile, I look forward to having more time to spend with my family.â€Mr Finnie is one of four list MSPs who currently write monthly columns for The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: The second phase of works under the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiativeand the Places and Spaces project is due to get underway at the beginning of next month.Orkney Islands Council is reporting that the works include new paving outside the Orkney Museum, a new parking area outside the former Spenceâ€™s newsagent and new paving into Victoria Street.This will take place from September until February, with work suspended through the whole of December to support shopping on the street during the festive period. Free parking of up to one hour will apply as usual in metered car parks over the winter period.Tankerness Lane will be closed to vehicles throughout the works, with one-way systems in place at ious times on Broad Street and Palace Road â€” with Victoria Street closed to vehicles for approximately five weeks from  January . Pedestrian access will be maintained throughout.The council has said the key aspects of the Place and Spaces project are to improve the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, provide a new path to the war memorial to enhance it as a place to stop and reflect on the signicance of the monument and improve the head of Victoria Street to encourage more people into this part of theÂ town.Depute council leader, councillor Leslie Manson, said: â€œThe works carried out in Kirkwallâ€™s town centre through our Townscape Heritage Initiative Scheme have given our streets and buildings a much-needed new lease of le, whether that be improvements to the shop fronts or the attractive new paving at the head of Broad Street.â€œThis latest phase is aimed at improving the entrance to Victoria Street to encourage more shoppers and visitors to take a wander down this street â€” a long-held aspiration of the businesses that are situated there.â€œThere will, of course, be some inevitable disruption, but weâ€™ve worked hard to ensure that this is kept to a minimum, including suspending works for the Christmas period. title: work set to begin at scapa flow museum
story: Work to restore and improve the Scapa Flow Museum is set to begin next month, Orkney Islands Council has said.This follows a recent decision by the local authority to take forward a revised project at Lyness.The council has said the aim is to concentrate efforts on renovating the historic pump house and on building an extension to the museum, with an Orkney-based company recently appointed to carry out the work. A refurbished and extended museum is expected to re-open during the summer of .Council leader James Stockan said: â€œThis is a project of tremendous signicance for Hoy and for Orkney as a whole.â€œIt has taken longer than we first hoped to get to this stage and it will be excellent for all involved to see work getting underway soon.â€œI am delighted that, like the council, the projectâ€™s external funders remain fully committed to the scheme.â€œWhen complete, the restored and extended museum will for the first time in many years open all year round, encouraging more people to visit Hoy and boosting tourism throughout the island.â€The museumâ€™s role is to chart Orkneyâ€™s military involvement in the First and Second World Wars and provide a safe home for a major collection of wartime artefacts, many of national and international importance.After a competitive tendering exercise, the contract for the work has been awarded to Orkney BuildersLtd.A temporary exhibition on the wartime history of Scapa Flow is on show at the Hoy Hotel while the museum is closed. This has been part-funded through the Island of Hoy Development Trust.Repairs to the Romney Hut at Lyness and options for the Oil Tank will be considered at a later date.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: pound-slides-news-pms-plan-prorogue-parliament
story: Pound coinsThe value of the pound has crashed lower after traders were spooked by news that the Government is expected to suspend Parliament from mid-September.Although sterling recouped some of its losses after going into ldquofreefall when the news was first announced on Wednesday morning, it still slumped to a six-day low.Downing Street confirmed that Boris Johnson has spoken to the Queen to request that Parliament is suspended until October .The Prime Minister insisted the move will allow him to bring forward a ldquobold and ambitious legislative agenda, but he has faced staunch criticism that it could stle opposition to a no-deal Brexit.Pound traders have interpreted the plans as increasing the possibility of a no-deal Brexit, weakening sentiment against both the dollar and euro.Sterling slid .% to . against the dollar in early trading, while it also fell .% to . against the euro.Hmm #sterling is not taking this news well #prorogue pic kKVxUCdemdash Anna MacdonaldAugust , Analysts have said the value of the pound will remain under pressure and continue to fluctuate while the future of Brexit is ldquounclear.The slide comes after a steady recovery in the currency over the past fortnight, after it hit a two-year low against the dollar.Since April, the value of the pound has fallen by .% against the US currency as the probability of leaving the EU without a deal increased.The major London markets actually benefited from the poundrsquos fall, with a signicant proportion of earnings from the UKrsquos biggest firms generated overseas.The FTSE  has risen .%, or . points, to , points in early trading.But domestic-focused sectors, such as housebuilders, have suffered as a result, with Taylor Wimpey, Persimmon and Barratt Developments all slumping more than % on title: supermarkets-continuing-mislead-customers-dodgy-deals--
story: Food shoppingSupermarkets appear to be disregarding Government pricing guidelines by using misleading discounts and special offers, according to an investigation.Consumer group Which  analysed  ldquooffers to find multi-buy deals that cost shoppers more than buying the items separately just one week before, as well as ldquodubious discounts and so-called special prices that were in place for most of the year.Among the misleading deals was Icelandrsquosoffer of Kelloggrsquos Crunchy Nut cereal at two packs for pound when customers could have bought them inidually for pound. a week earlier, the watchdog reported. Asda labelled Wallrsquos one litre Carte DrsquoOr Strawberry Ice Cream as ldquowas pound. now pound, despite selling the product at the lower price for more of the year than the higher price.Morrisons promoted Cathedral City Mature Cheddar Cheeseas ldquowas pound. now pound for the week of September  last year when the product had been available for the lower price of pound the month before.The Government rolled out new guidance to ensure that retailers complied with consumer law over pricing practices after Which  lodged a ldquosuper complaint with the Competition and Markets Authorityinto the issue in .The rules state that retailers must ensure the information they present to consumers is fair and does not waste time or cause annoyance, disappointment or regret.In addition, information must not cause a consumer to overspend or buy a product that is inappropriate for them.However, Which  said its latest investigation appeared to reveal that many UK supermarkets continued to flout the rules by offering deals that do not necessarily constitute a legitimate saving.It urged shoppers to be vigilant of ldquododgy deals, but is also demanding that supermarkets comply with Government guidelines and provide clearer pricing.Which  said it would be reporting its findings to the CMA.Natalie Hitchins, Which  head of home products and services, said: ldquoFour years on from our super complaint on misleading pricing practices, many of the big supermarkets are clearly still in the wrong, with numerous examples of dodgy discounts and never-ending offers.ldquoThese retailers must stop tricking shoppers with deceptive deals and spurious special offers. If not, the CMA must intervene to ensure that pricing guidelines are followed.An Iceland spokeswoman said: ldquoWe update our promotions throughout the year to offer the best possible value to our customers, and review our approach to pricing structures to ensure savings to the customer are as transparent as possible.ldquoWe have incorporated the findings shared by Which  into this process and will continue to review and improve our promotional calendar.Tom Ironside, director of business and regulation at the British Retail Consortium, said:ldquoSupermarkets seek to provide the best value for consumers on the hundreds of thousands of product lines they sell. This is often through promotions and discounts, which can change week to week, even on the same product lines, as retailers seek to cut the cost for shoppers.copy -. title: sturgeon-laments-dark-day-democracy
story: Boris Johnson and Nicola SturgeonNicola Sturgeon has said it will be a dark day for democracyBoris Johnson is not stopped from suspending Parliament.Writing on Twitter, Scotlandrsquos First Minister also challenged the Prime Minister to call a General Election before the October  Brexit deadline.Parliament will be temporarilyshut down from around September  until the state opening on October  under the PMrsquos plan.So it seems that Boris Johnson may actually be about to shut down Parliament to force through a no deal Brexit. Unless MPs come together to stop him next week, today will go down in history as a dark one indeed for UK democracy. https:t.co lFnEgiyrmdash Nicola SturgeonAugust , It would leave just a matter of weeks before the UK is set to leave the EU and means there would be little time for any legislation to be passed by opposition MPs in the House of Commons to stop a no-deal.ldquoSo it seems that Boris Johnson may actually be about to shut down Parliament to force through a no deal Brexit, Ms Sturgeon tweeted.ldquoUnless MPs come together to stop him next week, today will go down in history as a dark one indeed for UK democracy.ldquoGiven her past statements opposing a no deal Brexit, it would be good to have confirmation from Ruth Davidson today that all Scots Tory MPs will back the cross party effort next week to stop it ndash and that they will also oppose Boris Johnsonrsquos attempt to shut down Parliament.Following a surprise announcement on Tuesday thatChancellor Sajid Javid will set out Whitehall spending budgets next week, speculation was also fuelled there could be a snap General Election. Ms Sturgeon told Boris Johnson to call one before the end of October.The First Minister tweeted: ldquoBring it on. Have the courage of your convictions, Boris Johnson.ldquoCall an election now ndash with polling day before Oct  ndash and let the people vote. Or are you frit It was also announced on Wednesday that petitioners who launched legal action to stop Boris Johnson from suspending Parliament are considering the option of pursuing an emergency ruling from the courts.A cross-party group of more than  MPs and peers has indicated it will now consider seeking an interim interdict ndash similar to an injunction in England and Wales ndash at the Court of Session in Edinburgh to block prorogation, with a hearing currently scheduled for September .Scottish Labour MP Ian Murray, one of the petitioners, said:ldquoBoris Johnsonrsquos plan to suspend Parliament is an assault on our democracy.ldquoThis is the peoplersquos Parliament and the people deserve to have their representatives in Parliament during this vital period. This is the opposite of taking back control.ldquoLegal action to prevent the Prime Minister suspending Parliament has already been fast-tracked through the courts and the legal team will now consider the appropriate next steps, including seeking interim orders. -- vw,vw,px, px"Ruth Davidson has been urged to oppose the Prime Ministerrsquos move--Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie urged Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson to condemn the move by Mr Johnson.ldquoThis is an Eton coup and a democratic outrage, he said.ldquoI hope that Ruth Davidson will join the chorus of condemnation that this decision deserves and confirm that Scottish Conservatives will oppose any measures to prevent parliament having its say.ldquoThis process began with a democratic vote, it must not end with a behind closed doors stitch up.Scottish Greens co-Leader Patrick Harvie said: ldquoBoris Johnson led a Leave campaign which cheated and broke the law to win.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that now hersquos the Prime Minister he is continuing his assault against democracy.ldquoIf we need to lsquotake back controlrsquo from anyone, we need to take it back from him.ldquoThe people of Scotland are used to the UK Government treating them with contempt but this move by Johnson takes this contempt to a whole new level and reinforces the need for the people to have a say over the future direction of our country.copy -. title: lesley laird tories want us to work until we drop don t let them
story: Universal Credit has already shown just how cruel the Tories can be, but even more pain could be heading our way.The Centre of Social Justicethink tank proposed recently to move the pension age to  by the year . The same think tank which, while chaired by Tory MP Iain Duncan Smith, dreamt up Universal Credit and played an instrumental part in its design a design which forces many terminally ill people back to work and deliberately delays crucial payments to some of the most vulnerable people in our society.Centre for Social Justice  Whoever picked that title obviously loves a misnomer.Based on current le expectancy rates in my Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath constituency, increasing the pension age to  would mean men would receive a state pension for around  months on average before they died, while for women it would be five years.After years of work, National Insurance contributions and saving for a pension, the time left to enjoy retirement would be brutally short.Working until you drop would be the norm for a great many of us. The CSJâ€™s lack of understanding about dferent types of work is painfully obvious. Imagine working as a carer, nurse, teacher, or in a factory until . I doubt that many of us would even get to our pension.So, while we are all being distracted by flag waving and Brexit, is this the future many Tories have in mind for us People used to say the Tories looked after elderly voters, but it now appears the elderly are an inconvenience.Who can forget the disastrous â€˜dementia taxâ€™ that derailed the Tory general election campaign in  For some, the Toriesâ€™ broken manesto commitment of free TV licences for over s could be considered a small matter.However, add in WASPI pension injustice and declining le expectancy and we get a very clear picture of a government that really doesnâ€™t care for the oldest and most vulnerable in our society.No matter how you dress it up the â€˜Nastyâ€™ Tory Party is alive and kicking in .But it doesnâ€™t have to be like this.The work of the last Labour government under Gordon Brown saw the introduction of pension tax credits, free bus travel, cold weather payments and free TV licences to the elderly.Under Labour there was an increase in le expectancy and a signicant reduction in pensioner poverty â€“ now being eroded under the Tories.Actions speak so much louder than words.A Labour government will restore dignity and fairness to the lives of our elderly, something they have earned and deserve.A Labour government will retain the triple lock on pensions to ensure that the state pension keeps pace with earnings and the cost of living.A Labour government will work to resolve the unfairness that has hurt so many WASPI women.We donâ€™t need any more policies from Iain Duncan Smith and the CSJ, we need a Labour government that will be compassionate and deliver for all of our society and we need it now.Lesley Laird is Shadow Secretary of State for ScotlandÂ©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: jets flew empty for 500 miles to pick up royals for aberdeen visit
story: Two empty jets were flown on behalf of Flybe some  miles as part of taking the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children to Aberdeen on Thursday, The Scotsman has learned.The revelation comes days after William and Kate were praised for using an economy flight from Norwich when Prince Harry and  Meghan have been criticised for a series of private jet trips.It is understood the empty flights made by the two -seat aircraft cost around four tonnes of carbon.An aviation source with knowledge of what happened said the plane which normally flies the route had been replaced by a Flybe-branded aircraft in an attempt to maximise press coverage for the company.Eastern Airways, which operates the route for Flybe, confirmed to The Scotsman it swapped a Loganair plane normally used for the flight for another of the same type of jet with Flybe markings. Eastern said this was so it would be â€œwholly compliant and in control of the operationâ€.The substitution involved an empty Embraer  jet being flown some  miles from Humberside airport to Norwich to pick up the Royal party and regular passengers.Loganairâ€™s own Embraer plane then also flew empty some  miles from Norwich to Aberdeen so it could operate the next flight back to Norwich.The Glasgow airline has been subcontracted by Eastern since February for weekday flights on the route.The source said: â€œAn Eastern Airways jet was flown empty from Humberside to Norwich and then flew the scheduled flight to Aberdeen with the Royals on board.â€¢ : William and Kate catch budget Â£ FlyBe flight to Scotland with royal childrenâ€œThe Loganair aircraft which normally flies this route for Flybe and Eastern flew from Aberdeen to Norwich as usual but then flew empty from Norwich to Aberdeen.â€œI guess it was to ensurethey had any Press coverage of the Royal travel, an aircraft with a Flybe logo flew them.â€œHeck of a carbon footprint to achieve it â€“ not exactly environmentally conscious.â€Royal author Phil Dampier had said: â€œThe contrast between William, Kate and family travelling on a budget flight to Scotland and Harry and Meghan using private jets couldnâ€™t be starker.â€œAt the very least they know they would have been criticisedthey had taken a private jet.â€Flybe said the decision to change the aircraft had been Easternâ€™s. It declined to comment on the claim that the switch was to gain publicity.Its spokeswoman said: â€œWe were delighted to welcome the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their family on board one of our flights again, this time operated by our franchise partner, Eastern Airways.â€œPlease note that operational decisions generally are managed exclusively by Eastern on any route they operate under the franchise agreement, hence we are not in the position to comment.â€â€¢ : Duke and Duchess of Sussex share new image of baby Archie Mountbatten-WindsorEastern Airways said it had chosen to switch the aircraft after being told the Royal party had booked onto the flight.General managerRoger Hage said: â€œFollowing a call and details provided late evening on Wednesday as to members of the Royal Family having been booked onto the service, and that armed Royal Protection Officers would accompany the family on-board, we elected, given this service is operated for Flybe by Eastern, to provide our own aircraft and crew, given the approvals and clearance required  to accommodate such.â€œThis then assured ourselves on our own Air Operators Certicate that we would be wholly compliant and in control of the operation in accordance with associated regulation.â€œHence we positioned an aircraft on a short -minute leg to facilitate the above.â€An Eastern Airways spokesperson added: â€œEastern Airways can confirm any decision as to which aircraft operated the Norwich-Aberdeen service on Thursday morning was entirely that of Eastern Airways and not that of Flybe and apologies to Flybe for any resulting confusion. Decisions taken wereto ensure operational control and responsibility remained that directly of Eastern Airways.â€A Loganair spokesman said: â€œOur aircraft have operated the [Norwich-Aberdeen] route on weekdays since we took on this commitment in February.â€œAny comment on tasking requests in relation to the contract is a matter for our customer.â€Â©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

story: was established as a community interest company in  by directors Marc Chivers, Esther Renwick and non-executive director Lauren Doughton.Moder Dy#s Esther Renwick and Aberdeenshire artist Norma D Hunter alongside an unusually large boat noost and boat draw at Bridge End, Burra. So far they have footed the bill for the company and its projects.Dr Chivers# expertise on Shetland boats and boat use has been combined with Dr Renwickâ€™s work on community monitoring of eroding coastal archaeology to create a pilot project recording the boat noosts of Burra, and their stories, with a view to expanding this to a Shetland-wide project.Moder Dy archaeologist Dr Renwick said: â€œFolk are getting older, those who remember the days where everyone had a small boat are sadly getting fewer. title: main stands down as shetland manager
story: Outgoing Shetland manager Kevin Main.The Shetland football team are looking for a new manager after Kevin Main decided to step down from the role.This comes just over a week after his side regained the Milne Cup in a dramatic penalty-shootout win over Orkney.Main had been in charge of the Shetland team for the last four years, and said that he had decided the time was right for someone  to step in and lead the squad towards the next Island Games in Guernsey.This decision #certainly was in my mind for a few months,# he said, and he added that last month#s win over Orkney had #confirmed things in my mind# in regards to his decision.He said he had talked over the decision with a few of the team#s senior players before telling the whole squad that he would be standing down.#I thanked them all,# he said.Main refused to be drawn over who would replace him, or who he might like to take on the job next, but he said: #anybody that comes in will inherit a fantastic bunch of players#.He said that although he will take a short break from the sport, he will #not be far from Shetland football#. raquo..

title: by election hustings updates as candidates clash
story: The first of the two by-election hustings is currently underway in Mareel#s auditorium.Eight of the prospective candidates are in attendance at the hustings, with Ukip#s Stuart Martin still on the mainland and the Conservative#s Brydon Goodlad unable to attend due to medical reasons. He is being represented by Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston.BBC Radio Shetland#s John Johnston is hosting the event, with all eight candidates being given a minute to introduce themselves and their policies before moving on to audience questions.Independent candidate Ian Scott provided an impassioned speech, saying that he hasÂ #stood specically steadfastly against the cuts, the Tories, the Liberal Democratsâ€ before. He also reacted angrily to the news that Mr Goodlad could not be in attendance, shaking his head as Mr Halcro Johnston explained his absence.SNP candidate Tom Wills began by saying that #Shetland is ready for a change# and asked for  months to show what he can achieve in Holyrood, while Lib Dem competitor Beatrice Wishart opened her speech with a defiant message: #If you want an MSP who will speak up for Shetland, Iâ€™m your woman#.The first question of the night revolved around transport, with Ms Wishart and Mr Wills clashing immediately, interrupting each other#s answers as Mr Johnston appealed for both candidates to let the other finish.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to Mr Wills# five-point transport plan by saying that #Tom WillsÂ has a load of great ideas but they wonâ€™t be delivered#, while independent candidate Ryan Thomson added that #nothing gets doneâ€ because â€œShetland is the pawnâ€ in mainland politics.Councillor George Smith directed a question at Mr Wills, asking him how he expected the SIC to afford one of his election pledges, free foot passengers on inter-island ferries.Mr Wills responded to say that this could be paid for #, and when# the Scottish government provided additional funding to the council.Mr Thomson criticised the NorthLink ferries in response to a question about increased capacity on the ferries. He focused his attack on the much-maligned sleeping pods, not for the first time, saying that we had been #lumbered# with these pods and said he was reticent to even call them pods, instead saying #it#s a chair#.#Bigger ships# and #daytime sailings# were potential solutions that Mr Thomson suggested as alternatives.On the subject of Brexit, only Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that he was in favour of Brexit, although he admitted that he voted to remain in the EU.Mr Scott and Mr Wills attacked the coalition of the Tories and the Lib Dems, with Mr Scott saying that the #Tories and Liberals approved austerity and that they hadÂ #turned to the racists and the fascists# which garnered wide applause.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to say it was #always very amusing listening to Ian but Iâ€™m afraid heâ€™s wrong#, which was met negatively by the audience.Mr Wills said that the SNP #could stop Brexit#, and added thatthey were pulled out of the EU by Westminster then a vote for independence could put Scotland back into the European Union.He expanded on Mr Scott#s point by saying the #reason why people voted for Brexit is because of the coalition of Lib Dems and Tories which approved austerity# to a rapturous reception. Ms Wishart responded to the issue of Brexit to say that it was #time for a peoples vote and time for people to work together across parties# to stop Brexit.Scottish independence was the next topic up for debate, and understandably provoked perhaps the most isive reactions of the night.Mr Scott, Mr Wills and the Green Party#s Debra Nicolson all came out in favour of an independent Scotland, while Mr Halcro Johnston, Ms Wishart and independent Peter Tait were against it. Both independent candidates, Michael Stout and Ryan Thomson, said they would wait to see what benefit Shetland could get from Scotland becoming independent before deciding how to vote, should another referendum come up.Mr Scott#s positive attitude towards independence was because, he said, # nothing  we#ll get rid of these damned Tories#.Ms Wishart wanted the audience to #imagine the chaos#Scotland tried to break up the union, citing Brexit as an example. She said the vote was supposed to be #once in a letime# and that there were better priorities for funding, such as healthcare.Mr Wills responded to this point: #which has been cut by the Tory Liberal coalition#, to audience applause.Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that #I think SNP talk about independence because its easier than talking about their failings#, and added that nobody would be surprised to find that he was against independence.I#m sorry, Tom Wills is havering. Independence will not keep Scots in, or bring us back into, the EU. EvenBritain stays in, Scotland will leave, automatically, with #No Deal#, on Independence Day and will have to reapply to join. The EU has confirmed this, in writing.Also,nothing changes, our starting budget deficit will be Â£. billion per annumversus the EU#s limit of about Â£ billion . The UK will stop paying funding that.We shall have to cut spending raise taxes by some Â£ billion p.a. on an annual budget of about Â£ billion, to satisfy the EU#s economic conditions for joining.That means we shall face years of withering austerity, just when we need to spend more to stimulate the economy.We also need to set up our own independent central bank which the nationalist think tank #The Common Weal# says will take nine years from an Indy Yes vote. So we shall be out of the EU, with #No Deal#, for at least, seven years from Independence Day.Scots are canny folk. They will not vote for such an independence prospectus.John, your oft repeated notion that an independent Scotland will start with a budget deficit of Â£. billionis an entire fancy. Whatdebt an independent Scotland may have to take on as a share of the current UK#s debt, in the event of Scotland becoming independent, will be a matter for negotiation and agreement . Similarly, matters such as whether, and for what fees , the rest of the former UK might be permitted to retain its weapons of mass destruction on Scottish soil will be for negotiation agreement in the event of Scotland becoming independent.I would not hold my breath waiting for their answer.Ian Scott and Tom Wills have very selective memories. The austerity cuts introduced by the last Conservative  Lib Dem coalition were in response to the mess Brown and Blair made of the British economy. The outcome of this prudent handling of the deficit was obviously popular with the British people because David Cameronâ€™s government won an overall majority in the subsequent election. David Cameron also delivered on another election pledge to have an in out referendum on Europe. How can the SNP criticise any party for that they have never delivered on an election pledge in their le. Finally, the only racism and fascism that has come out of this by-election has been promoted by the SNP anti-English racism. The SNP are Tartan Fascists.Had it not been for the global economic crisis, and Blair#s US led wars, Brown#s finances could have seen him becoming PM. This shows the harm in getting too friendly with the US, not that there will be much of a choice for the remnants of the UK after Brexit. I won#t digny John M Scott#s final comment with a response other than to note that it is Trump and Farage that have been too close to white supremacists. Happily neither seem that popular north of the boarder. The SNP promote an inclusive civic nationalism which can#t seriously be compared to that of the far right.##and the peril of getting too friendly with the EU is being dictated to and bled dry by a Union of Socialist Republics ruled by a Germanic Franco dictator, aided an abetted by a random collection of Belgians.Best off going it alone and not being shackled up to some #superpower#, either actual or wannabe.John M Scott#s remark reminds me of something a reviewer wrote in the Shetland News in : #The depths of ignorance are surely plumbed here#.It#s like I wasnt even there.No mention of Labours position on Brexit or Independence. Thanks guysYou#ll have to listen tonight folks, there isnt even any mention of VE which was discussedLabour has a position on Brexit!Where did you find out about this Johan @Brian Hill, It is you who fantasise, not I. I did not mention #national debt#. So let#s set aside the #smoke and mirrors#. I am talking about the Â£. billion gap between Scottish tax revenue raised last year and money received from Westminster. We have been running similar, sometimes larger deficits for many years. Unless something changes this will become our annual budget deficit on obtaining independence as Westminster will no longer fund the shortfall.Don#t take it from me. A couple of years back, the SNP#s own Sustainable Growth Commission conceded that we would start independence with a budget deficit of .% of our GDP, around Â£. billion per year, and proposed a multi-year plan to reduce it to less than %, which just happens to be the EU#s maximum permissible limit. @Brian Hill, Ok,we are to be pernickety:The UK funds the dference between our tax revenues and what Holyrood receives from the Exchequer so we are talking about a so-called #notional deficit# that has been ongoing for many years.This is recognised by the SNP#s Sustainable Growth Commission.UK funding will cease on Independence Day and the notional deficit will become , our budget deficit.The current UK funding of Â£. billion equates to around Â£ per head of population, per year. With independence that money will have to be found where # borrowing or tax hikes # or cut from public services.#John, as Scotland is not yet independent then it cant have been running a deficit for any#, what utter nonsense. Since when did you have to be independent to go broke  Try telling that one to your bank manager. Dr Craig Dalzell! who  wings over Scotland! still based in England, hard to make it up but you manage it Brian.John, I#m sorryit appeared pernickety, but my fundamental point was that you cant predict the future finances of any putative future independent Scotland based on the notionalaccounts of a devolved Scotland within the current UK state. No amount of repetition of thosefigures alters the arguments...

story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na DaoineFor several months local residents, particularly on Old Kyle Farm Road, have been concerned about the strong smell emanating from the facility, and also the noticeable humming and bleeping noises at night.On Tuesday of this week an open day was held at the plant, which employs over  people, to reassure locals that the issues are being dealt with.Senior Mowi managers Peter Nilsson and Claes Jonermark were on hand to explain what has been done to date and what they plan to do over the next few months.As far as the night-time noises are concerned, they come from feed boats that are using their own generators for power and from reversing alarms from attending vehicles.Mr Nilsson said an onshore power supply would be installed and reversing lights quietened to cut out the noise.
