Highland Council would be approached to seethey would agree to a -metre extension to the height of the chimney.As far as the feed boats are concerned, Mr Nilsson said the problem arises when the hatches are opened so that the fish meal can be delivered to the plant. This will occur for about  hours per year, he said, and the firm is currently working on a solution to that.Mr Jonermark added: #We do not want this to be a problem for anyone. We do not want this situation to continue.#We want to make a positive contribution to the village and we will continue to invest to make sure the problems go away. title: new stamp celebrates beauty on our doorstep
story: A much-loved beauty spot just a few miles from the centre of Ballymena has been celebrated on a new set of stamps that show off the beauty of the UKs forests. Glenarfe Forest Parkâ€™s famed Ess Na Grub waterfall is featured on the pound. stamp released to coincide with the th anniversary of the Forestry Commission.Amazingly, despite the proximity of the Forest Park to the town, a surprisingly large number of local people have admitted theyâ€™ve never been there!Well, they donâ€™t know what theyâ€™re missing!Glenarfe offers much more than a walk amongst the trees.Aside from its breathtaking waterfalls walk - ideal for selfies - the park boasts superb â€˜high walksâ€™ with wonderful views out towards Scotland.In the past few years, large sections of the forest have fallen victim to tree diseases but the resulting cutbacks have added to the rugged nature of the terrain andyou are looking for a tough but rewarding â€˜wellbeing walkâ€™, donâ€™t miss it!The Forestry Commission is a non-ministerial department of the government which manages forests owned by the public and also regulates public and private forests in England. It is responsible for protecting, improving and expanding forests and woodland in England. title: prevention programme aimed at stopping diabetes surge
story: A programme to tackle the increasing prevalence of type  diabetes by PHA is operational across the Ballymena area.Approximately , people are living with diabetes in Northern Ireland, a startling .% increase since [].Type  diabetes accounts for % of all cases of diabetes and is a serious and progressive condition. The disease can lead to early loss of le, cause preventable sight loss in working age people, and is a major contributor to kidney failure, heart attack, stroke and even amputation, yet the illness is often preventable by adopting healthier lestyle changes.The new Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic â€“ those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range â€“ by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.Cullybackey patient Thelma Shanks from Cullybackey was referred onto the programme this year. She said: â€œThere is a history of hypertension and diabetes in my family. â€œSeveral of my paternal aunts sadly passed away due to complications that came with the disease, and my mum was found to be diabetic following admission to hospital for routine tests. â€œI was born in London, but grew up in my parent country, Jamaica. I ed to the UK for good in , and my husband and I moved to Northern Ireland, where all my children were born, in . â€œAs a nation, we from the Caribbean tend to be a bit more susceptible to diabetes than others, so it wasnâ€™t a complete surprise to be told I was at risk of developing the disease. â€œI am also a trained doctor so despite having given up my profession when I had children, I have knowledge of the medical risk.â€œI have a wonderful busy family le. I have four children, all of which I home schooled, and of course, their needs always came before mine. â€œWhen youâ€™re running a busy house and looking after everyone  itâ€™s easy to forget to look after yourself. However, in  when I heard that a health fair was coming to the area I decided to go along. For a small fee they carried out multiple tests which showed I had hypertension or high blood pressure. â€œI decided to make an appointment with my GP who put me on a number of drugs, first Irbesartan, then Amlodipine and finally a diuretic to bring my blood pressure under control.â€œI realised I needed to be more careful with my diet and tried to be a bit healthier but I admit it was a bit half-hearted. TESTSâ€œMy blood sugar levels were border-line they werenâ€™t going down but they werenâ€™t going up either, so I thought everything was all right. I was having routine check-ups with my nurse at this stage so I was on her radar and having blood tests taken intermittently. In April  I had my regular tests done and then hopped on a plane to London. â€œIt was my daughterâ€™s birthday and I had decided to treat her by going away for the week. We had just made it to the hotel when I received a phone call from my nurse. â€œShe said tests showed my sugar levels were up and I was actually diabetic, which was the wake-up call I needed. Letâ€™s just say it wasnâ€™t quite the luxury week that I had planned! My daughter certainly ate well, but no sugar passed my lips that trip. â€œNeedless to say, I had the blood tests repeated soon after our , and was delighted to learn that due to my dietary sacrices, my blood sugar levels had again receded into the â€˜pre-diabeticâ€™ band.â€œPrior to our trip away, my doctor had called me. She said there was a new Diabetes Prevention Programme starting soon in my area being run by the Public Health Agency. She askedI would be interested and of course I agreed.â€œThe class has  others in it and we meet on Wednesday afternoons. There are eight women and two men, and together we re-learn what we should be eating, what to avoid, and how to step up our exercise routines. â€œIâ€™ve found it really helpful because everyone is in the same boat and we can share our experiences and encourage one another. â€œEach week we build on the goals of the previous weeks, paying attention to diet and exercise and gaining strength from each other.â€œI used to believe that running after a busy family was exercise enough but now Iâ€™m walking every other day, trying to increase my pace and my distance. My daughter and I often walk together and I try to keep up with her. LONG TERMâ€œOne day I managed , steps in one walk and  of those miles were uphill. Iâ€™m trying to make long term changes and make sure these become habits Iâ€™ll stick to for the rest of my le. So far Iâ€™ve lost  kg, and my exercise levels have increased signicantly too. My blood sugar levels have decreased, but more importantly I feel better physically and psychologically. â€œThe Diabetes Prevention Programme and the team who deliver it have been amazing. Iâ€™m looking forward to seeing a new me at the end of the nine and a half month course.â€Thelma was referred onto the Diabetes Prevention Programme by her GP Dr Jean McCaughern, Maine Medical Practice, CullybackeyThe practice serves around , patients that live within a six mile radius of the surgery. Dr Jean McCaughern joined the surgery around  years ago and was placed in charge of the practiceâ€™s diabetes clinic.At first she managed this alone, today she heads up this specialist clinic with the help of two practice nurses. She does this alongside her normal GP responsibilities.She said: â€œWhen I first started the clinic around % of our patients were diabetic and that included those who had both type  and type  diabetes. Today that figure has more than doubled. In  we have a prevalence rate of .%. Thatâ€™s how quickly the disease is on the rise. â€œOften patients donâ€™t realise just how serious the illness is. I have overheard patients saying â€˜I just have a touch of diabetesâ€™ or â€˜I only have diabetesâ€™, but itâ€™s a serious illness which can cause deterioration of vision, contribute to heart disease, kidney disease, stroke, and vascular problems which at their worst can lead to amputation.â€œPatients of mine have had all these problems and more. The reality is dferent to the perception and itâ€™s only when dficulties start that people begin to understand what living with diabetes can mean. The longer you have the disease, the more likely you are to have any one of those complications.â€œHaving diabetes presents practical problems too. In some cases the DVLA can revoke peopleâ€™s drivers licensestheythey believe there is poor management of diabetes. This can include raised sugars, but more importantly sugar levels dropping and causing confusion in patients as is would be unsafe to drive.â€œFor some people having diabetes is out of their control. Those with Type  diabetes have no choice but to manage it using medication. â€œFor others who spot heightened blood sugar levels early, termed pre-diabetic, they have a window of opportunity to reverse or delay a diagnosis of Type  diabetes through healthy eating and exercise. Thatâ€™s who the Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at and who it can help.â€œOnce higher sugar levels are discovered, the earlier people can make changes and the higher the chance they have of reversing the outcome. Sometimes, itâ€™s not about changing the diagnosis but delaying it by a decade or so. â€œThe longer you can hold it off the longer you can hold off the complications that come with it. â€œItâ€™s not all bad news though, having diabetes, whether Type  or Type , is largely manageable either by medication, treatment or diet. â€œInsulin, used primarily for treating type  diabetes, lowers blood sugar levels when diet and exercise alone arenâ€™t sufficient, but the effectiveness of these medications depends on how early the disease is diagnosed and the size of the dose.â€œI was happy to get involved in the Programme. Having an interest in diabetes I was approached by the Public Health Agency at the operational stage to look at the programmeâ€™s viability in my area. Iâ€™m a big supporter. â€œSo far Iâ€™ve referred around  people from the practice onto the programme which educates and empowers people of the contents of foods, the need to exercise and develop better eating patterns. â€œOften Iâ€™ve heard people say once they have to go on a special diabetes diet but thatâ€™s not the case, itâ€™s just healthy eating, itâ€™s the way we should all be eating.â€œAs far as the success of the programme goes, itâ€™s a little early to tell. The first cohort of people started on the programme in May and early results are positive. Certainly weight loss as a group has occurred and people have more knowledge of food, portion control and exercise.â€œSo, there are benefits for all and for some the course is working really well. When you join the programme as a group you bond as a group, you encourage each other, you donâ€™t want to let your group members down. â€œThat shared experience and cohesiveness is a real motivator and works across all ages and all groups. For many the programme offers them a chance to turn a future diagnosis around and gives them the tools to change their future. â€œThat can be le changing and what the programme is designed to doâ€.KEY FACTSThe Diabetes Prevention Programme is run by the Public Health Agency.It is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic â€“ those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range â€“ by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.The Diabetes Prevention Programme is delivered over a nine month period and is free of charge.It is facilitated by health coaches who offer help and assistance to participants, helping them change their lestyle, diet and physical activity with the aim of postponing and even preventing type  diabetes.For more information on the â€˜Diabetes Prevention Programmeemail your local Health Trustdiabetespreventionni@northerntrust.hscni.netst

title: car goes up in flames after teenagers come to driver s aid
story: Two teenagers from Co Down have been praised for their brave actions in helping a man escape from his car before it went up in flames.Sean Kelly, , and Joshua Allen, , spotted smoke coming from the grille of the manâ€™s car in the village of Dromore shortly after pm yesterday and raised the alarm.Sean Kelly and Joshua Allen, the Dromore teenagers who rescued a man from a car which caught fireJoshua said: â€œWe were on our way back from the shop. You could see smoke and a small bit of flames coming out of the car, I knew the engine was on fire.â€œSean and I were straight over to him and told him he needed to get out of the car. He had no idea what was going on. â€œWe got him out of the car and pushed it off the road. We got his stuff out of the car and popped the hood. â€œI phoned the fire brigade and Sean and I redirected traffic to keep them away from the car until they came.â€œThe fire started to escalate, within Iâ€™d say about  seconds of popping the hood the engine was fully on fire.â€œThankfully the fire brigade got there before the petrol tank went up.â€Joshua guessed the man, whom they helped back to his house in the village with the items they helped rescue from the car, was in his fties or sixties. A video has been circulated on social media of part of the incident and praise has been heaped on Sean and Joshua for their brave actions.Joshua commented: â€œIt happened so quickly, natural instincts took over. title: front door side door always a welcome
story: BORN and bred in North Belfast, Brendan Rafferty is a well-known figure to many in the food and catering industry. With over thirty years experience in the field, he has been the head chef, first manager and then owner of the popular The Side Door restaurant, located at Febro Buildings on the Antrim Road in Glengormley for  years.Brendan grew up on the Cltonville Road until he was  years old when his parents moved to the Antrim Road. His first part-time job came in the old Lansdowne Court as it was known back in the day.Ever since a young age, Brendan was interested in the food and catering industry and decided to pursue a career in the field when he left school at . After three years at the College of Business in Brunswick Street in Belfast, he went on to complete a B-Tech qualication and an advanced catering course.Subsequent employment followed in the shape of a full-time role in the Lansdowne before spells in Belfast Castle, the Crawfordsburn Inn and Chimney Corner.But it is with his current venture The Side Door that he has made his name, establishing the -seater restaurant ever since taking over six years ago as the new owner.Brendan explained: â€œThe Side Door is basically a family-style restaurant with something on the menu for everyone. The menu is very mainstream.â€œThe previous ownerâ€™s menu was something close to fine dining but people were still ordering pizzas. I thought it wasnâ€™t right so I changed the menu about a bit.â€œI had my own ideas and kept it mainstream to attract anybody and everybody.â€œThe pressure was there to get bums on seats and it has worked ever since so I have no intention of changing it.â€Brendan also acts as Head Chef at The Side Door and thanks to his wealth of experience, he has put his own style and spin on food.â€œI would cook things like lasagne, carbonara, scampi and burgers,â€ he added.â€œEverything is home-made. I am experienced enough to know what way things are cooked best and what sells well.â€œI used to be a sauce chef and I suppose sauces and soups are still my forte.It is still probably my favourite aspect of being in the kitchen.â€œI was brought up in the catering industry on a French theme which is something I still like doing, especially with some of the specials in the restaurant in some shape or form.â€As for how things have changed in the industry, Brendan points to a number of ious things he has noticed over the years.â€œThe food industry has changed massively over the years,â€ he explained.â€œThemes and customers needs and wants are like night and day now since when I started off over  years ago.â€œFood takes waves now, much like politics. whether Italian or Mexican themed.â€œThere are more vegans and vegetarians than ever before but allergies is such a big thing these days. Celiac is definitely the main one and you just have to be so careful.â€œI probably wouldnâ€™t have taken as much of an interest in allergies but when I found out my daughter had a nut allergy, it changed everything. It scared me.â€Looking ahead to the future, Brendan reflected on what he has achieved so far at The Side Door.â€œGlengormley is a perfect setting. People thought I was mad taking The Side Door on with the amount of competition but my idea wasyou want to buy a washing machine and there is more than one shop available in the same area to buy it, you will still compare it, just like restaurants.â€œI think we stand out because we are not pretentious. Many restaurants are, in my opinion. We are not â€“ what you see is what you get: fresh food bought from a number of dferent suppliers who I have built up a relationship with over the years. I buy the best produce that I can get but at affordable prices for customers.â€œI believe also in good service and to my knowledge, we are still the only bring-your-own restaurant in Glengormley.â€œAs for the future, I am not getting any younger. I thought around two years ago about looking for a bigger premises. What I have to turn away from a Thursday to a Sunday now is scary some weeks, but I thought here was working. I decided to stay because things are good and long may it continue.â€œCustomers keep coming back so I must be doing something right.â€Brendan Rafferty is Owner, Manager and Head Chef at The Side Door restaurant in Glengormley.The Side Door,Febro Buildings,Ballyclare Road,Glengormley,BT DZ.Tel:

title: speckled hen have got it well sussed
story: IN a food market dominated by commercial farming, big drinks brands and unormity, the authenticity and quality yielded by do-it yourself approach is becoming all the more appealing, and there are few businesses doing it better locally than the Speckled Hen Bar and Dining Rooms.Having long brewed an exciting range of its own craft beers and ciders, the Lisburn-based establishment has taken the next crucial step towards self-suffiency by bottling its own still and sparkled water. Although a seemingly simple step, tapping into the natural springs below the bar has revealed interesting information about the geography of the area and, as owner Martin Caldwell explains, has created further links to the Speckled Henâ€™s -year history.â€œRight under our feet is the Triassic Aquer, which stretches from the Castlereagh to Black Mountain,â€ he said.â€œThere has always been a well under the bar, so given that weâ€™re filtering our own water anyway, it made sense to put in a chiller, a cooler and a carbonator to make fizzy water too.â€œThere was originally a well there and the previous owner had tapped into it. During the winter time you can actually see little springs coming up out in the carpark. There used to be a well where our beer garden is now where they used to dip the buckets for water. The pub goes back to , so it goes back a fair while. They used to brew their own beers and everything here, so access to spring water was vital.â€He continued: â€œItâ€™s fantastic that a place of this age is still ing and providing hospitality and services. This used to be the old post road and was also one of the main roads to Dublin at the time, so coaches used to stop along here. It was actually alleged that Daniel Oâ€™Connell stopped here before. It would have had to have been self-sufficient. Weâ€™re essentially going back to the notion of our own self-sufficiency in terms of the supply of water as well.â€The Speckled Hen started bottling its water last month, installing a new filtration system that provides fresh four-times-filtered water for its customers. The water is, of course, filtered through the rocks on its journey across the mountains that, according to Queenâ€™s University researchers, began , to , years ago. As for the punters, Martin says they see it as a â€œgreat noveltyâ€.â€œTheyâ€™re getting their draft beer and now they are getting draft water, he said.â€œThe kids come in and want cordials or juices, so now well ask themthey want still or fizzy water â€“ they think itâ€™s a great novelty getting the fizzy water in the cordial.â€While making connections with the pubâ€™s past, Martin and his team are also looking to the future with the installation of farming allotments that will provide fruit, veg and more for itâ€™s kitchens in the years to come.

while over , children remain on its waiting list.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland -children-on-waiting-list-yet-trust-s-half-its-funds-for-autism-services-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece f AUTOCROP h -_Read-Only_.jpgEmailA Northern Ireland health trust ed over half the money it was allocated for autism services - while over , children remain on its waiting list..pushThe Western Trust has apologised for the delays that parents of autistic children face in getting either treatments or assessment.But one mother whose four-year-old daughter is autistic said the underspend was "totally unacceptable".The Department of Health had allocated a total of Â£, for autism services across all five health trusts, with each trust getting Â£,.The Western Trust was unable to complete recruitment and surrendered Â£,.Jacyln Harron, whose daughter Aoe has been on the waiting list for occupational therapy for  months and could face an additional wait of at least  months, said autistic children are being let down.She said: "The total allocation for autism services in Northern Ireland is a disgrace, but it is shocking that the Western Trust ed more than half of the money it was given."There are private practitioners that will do diagnosis, sothe trust couldnt recruit staff the money could have been used for private practitioners."If they didnt have the money to pay private practitioners, then fair enough, but they are ing money and that is totally unacceptable when you think how long parents wait on services."Aoe had been on waiting lists for speech therapy, a place at a specialist nursery, but she eventually got those. She has been on a waiting list for  months for occupational therapy and we have been told we will have another year to wait."Ms Harron said she enquired about the cross-border health directive, where EU citizens have the right to access healthcare in any EU country and to be reimbursed by their home country.She hoped to get her daughter assessed by an occupational therapist in Donegal and claim the money back through the directive, but claimed the trust didnt reply to her letter.Ms Harron added: "Getting a child with autism the relevant treatments and assessments is so important, because it can make the dference in your child being allocated a full-time classroom assistant at school."It also helps parents cope with the additional needs a child with autism has."The Western Trusts failure to spend the money came to light through a Freedom of Information request submitted by SDLP MLA Mark H Durkan.He said: "We are all too well aware of the y delays in diagnoses and waits for support and help which are often explained away by the trust as a result of insufficient resources to meet the demand on autism services. However, now we have a situation where the trust actually received money to improve its performance in service for autism and it seems it has been unable to spend that money."From the information I have received, all other trusts in Northern Ireland havent had the same dficulty in spending the money and recruiting new staff."The Western Trust spokeswoman said: "The Western Trust was allocated funding by the HSCB to facilitate the development and implementation of a new regional framework for the delivery of children and young peoples emotional wellbeing, autism and ADHD services. "The HSCB withdrew part of the funding from the original allocation as it was dficult to recruit staff within the required timeframe. "The trust has, however, recently appointed one band-six social worker to address the extensive waiting list for children and young people for intervention following a diagnosis of ASD."In relation to childrens autism services, there are  on the assessment waiting list and  on the treatment waiting list as at end of July . "The trust apologies for theof time waiting for both assessment and intervention and is committed in its efforts to reduce waiting times and enhance service provision for children with a diagnosis of autism and their families across the Western Trust area."

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandChamber chief hails â€˜creative thinkingâ€™ shown following Belfast Primark inferno data-dfpadtargetingRajesh Rana said the fire helped galvanise local organisationsRajesh Rana said the fire helped galvanise local organisationsBy Margaret CanningTwitterEmailAugust   CommentsChamber chief hails â€˜creative thinkingâ€™ shown following Belfast Primark infernoBelfastThe fire at Belfast city centres Primark prompted a continuing rethink of how to make the city centre more family-friendly, according to the president of the citys Chamber of Trade and Commerce.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland chamber-chief-hails-creative-thinking-shown-following-belfast-primark-inferno-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece aae AUTOCROP h imark_Fire...Ge.jpgEmailThe fire at Belfast city centres Primark prompted a continuing rethink of how to make the city centre more family-friendly, according to the president of the citys Chamber of Trade and Commerce..pushRajesh Rana was into his third month in the post when the fire at Bank Buildings broke out. It led to many months of disrupted business for retailers and shoppers in the area after a cordon was put in place around the unsafe building. "We all really felt it," he said.Read MoreClaire McNeilly: Why do we still not know how Belfast Primark fire started In October alone footfall was down % on the year before. Fast food restaurant City Picnic closed on the day of the fire and hasnt been opened since, though hopes to be open again by the autumn. Others such as Pizza Boutique struggled on for a time after the cordon was reduced, only to also shutter their premises completely.Primark opened two stores, one at the back of its Bank Buildings shop and another on Donegall Place - though it is also planning a restoration of Bank Buildings. Fashion chain Zara was closed for around seven months, thanks to its close proximity to Bank Buildings.Mr Rana said the first impact had been to galvanise organisations in the city to work together with a greater sense of urgency than ever before. "There was Belfast City Council, then ourselves in the Chamber, then the other business-type organisations like Belfast City Centre Management and also the Department for Communities, and Translink."It did throw us together and resulted in a great deal of co-ordination and co-working. Its probably strengthened that relationship and added impetus to work together."That led to initiatives to draw people into the city centre around Christmas, such as a winter-themed slide in Royal Avenue and stalls selling fast food. When it wasnt ing we all really felt it."He said retail was the biggest pull into the city centre, but that the night-time economy and the drive to get more people living in it were also a big part of planning its future. "And in Belfast, we still have our big-brand retailers like House of Fraser, Debenhams and Marks  Spencer - retailers which have closed stores in other city centres."And he said other parts of the city centre were being redeveloped, such as a site close to Smithfield Market and the Tribeca development around the Cathedral Quarter. The Tribeca name has attracted objections as its also the name of a district in New York. But Mr Rana said he did not object to the name. "The name gives definition to the area and at the end of the day, the priority isnt the name but making sure development starts, proceeds and benefits the city centre."

The results relate to the   academic year and include the core GCSE subjects, English and maths.GCSE school league table - check out the full list hereThe five schools in joint first place are Loreto Grammar School in Omagh, Lumen Christi College in Londonderry, Dalriada School in Ballymoney, Rainey Endowed School in Magherafelt and Friends School Lisburn.In joint sixth place are Our Lady and St Patricks College Belfast, Wallace High School, Lisburn, and St Dominics High School Belfast.In joint ninth place are St Louis Grammar School, Ballymena, and Dominican College, Belfast.In th place is Assumption Grammar School, Ballynahinch.Four of the top  schools are all-girl grammars, while the rest are co-educational grammars.Grammar schools claimed the top  places in the league table.The top-performing non-grammar school was Castlederg High School, which ranked th in this years table with .% of pupils achieving five or more top GCSE grades. It was followed by St Kevins College in Enniskillen in st place with .%, and, both in joint nd place, St Catherines College in Armagh and St Michaels College in Enniskillen with .%.Dalriada School headmaster Tom Skelton said he was "absolutely delighted" with the results."Its a fantastic achievement for the staff and pupils involved," he said. "To take every child over the line with % five A*-C represents a lot of hard work and the support of parents as well."Two years ago we were % as well, so were delighted to get up there again. I think it reflects well on the school, the pupils and the standards set by staff."Mr Skelton said the league table "shows the success of the grammar school system" and he added: "Pastoral care is a massive part of it. We have a very simple saying, Happy pupils, high expectation, high achievement and thats it in a nutshell."The school is well led by a supportive board of governors."Principal of Loreto Grammar, Omagh, Grainne OHanlon, said she was "delighted" at its joint top ranking, the first time it has topped the league table."It is the result of the professional relationship and trust which the teachers establish with the pupils," she said. "Theres a strong, supportive pastoral Special Educational Needs and safe environment surrounding the pupils and thats fully endorsed by the parents."Its the overriding belief that our young girls are creative, talented and able, and with a lot of self belief and hard work they can achieve."Lumen Christi College principal Siobhan McCauley said her schools academic success is largely due to "the excellent relationships that exist between students and staff".She added: "The strong support of parents coupled with the hard work and dedication of the staff enables our students, who are well-motivated and enthusiastic, to perform at the highest level and thus achieve outstanding exam results."Principal of Rainey Endowed Mark McCullough said the results were enabled by a "three-way partnership between the school, parents and pupils"."Its a great accolade - we just work and do the best for them that we can," he said."Im absolutely delighted and would like to thank everybody for all their hard work."Principal of St Dominics in Belfast Carol McCann said that % of all GCSE grades achieved in her school were A* A."Our performance at GCSE is the highest it has ever been in the A* A grades," she said. "We are very proud of the achievement, which is down to the hard work of the pupils, staff and parents, who have worked together."Our Lady and St Patricks College principal Deborah McLaughlin said her schools joint sixth position was "testament to the positive attitude of our students, who are supported by our committed staff and our parent body"."Were very much a team," she said. "It is a balance between academic and extracurricular activities for students."Principal of St Louis Grammar School in Ballymena Sean Rafferty paid tribute to the work of pupils, staff and teachers."I would like to congratulate the pupils, teachers and parents for their magnicent effort. Its about hard work and dedication," he said of its joint ninth place.Principal of Castlederg High School Elaine McKelvey said she was "delighted" it was the highest-ranking non-grammar school in the league table."These results are testimony to the excellent provision for learning made at Castlederg High School by a highly dedicated staff, working in partnership with very supportive parents to ensure the best possible outcome for each young person," she said.Mrs McKelvey paid tribute to the hard work and dedication of staff during "a most challenging period for educational delivery within all schools in Northern Ireland, given the shortfall in capital funding and inequitable remuneration for teaching staff"."Most of all though, we are tremendously proud of our pupils and their achievements, noting the breadth of opportunity for the future that such excellent exam results have created for them," she added.The Department of Education said the information contained in the league table relating to GCSE results "does not provide a valid basis for comparing performance between schools, since it takes no account of intakes of the schools or of any other factors that may affect pupil performance".It added: "No single measurement can constitute a fair or accurate evaluation of a school, and the figures should be considered in the context of other information about schools and their pupils."

story: The Nerve Visual Gallery at Ebrington is set to close at the beginning of next month, the Derry News has learned.The announcement will come as a great disappointment to art lovers in the city who have frequented the gallery over the past number of years and will be a loss to the Ebrington site.When it first opened in  it was lauded as a â€œmajor new venue for visual arts in the Northern Irelandâ€.However, at the weekend a spokesperson for The Executive Officeconfirmed: â€œThe Nerve Centre has operated a gallery in a section of the Creative Hub Building   on the Ebrington Site for three years and gave notice that they intend to close the gallery on  September .â€œThe Executive Office is currently considering options for the section occupied by Nerve Gallery.â€Located in the former army barracks at Ebrington, the Nerve Centre developed a series of major visual arts commissions with partners including - Now, National Museums NI, The Fondation Gilles Caron, Gallery of Photography Dublin, Ultra Lab Madrid and Matts Gallery London.Exhibitions have shone a light on pivotal moments in Northern Irelandâ€™s history such as the Civil Rights movement and the Troubles.The Lost Moment exhibition looked anew at the Civil Rights movement fty years on from the marches and peaceful protests that immediately preceded the Troubles. It featured dramatic images of the famous Selma to Montgomery civil rights march in , alongside work on the Northern Irish civil rights struggle, from the first march in August  to the Battle of the Bogside in .Picturing Derry brought together some of the most iconic images from the Troubles and the most recent exhibition explored anxieties around Brexit which were part of a series of cross-border projects.Local artists were also regularly showcased at the gallery.Earlier this year plans to build a whiskey distillery in Ebrington fell through.But last week positive news emerged of plans to build two Grade A office blocks and a -apartment retirement village at the Waterside site.The Nerve Centre was contacted for comment regarding the galleryâ€™s closure but did not respond at the time of going to press.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: new cain documents highlight unresolved political issues
story: A new batch of documents added to Ulster Universityâ€™s CAIN archive demonstrate how important issues affecting Northern Irish politics twenty years ago remain pertinent today.The newly released material provides a valuable insight into the period between -, mostly notably in relation to the Brooke Mayhew talks.In addition, it also charts developments in Anglo-Irish relations for these years, ongoing discussions around ious political and security matters, as well as important issues such as fair employment, the Irish language and community relations.The Brooke Mayhew negotiations took place to secure â€œa new, more broadly based agreementâ€ which would replace the Anglo Irish Agreement.On the  March, , the first roundtable negotiations, excluding Sinn Fein, took place in an attempt to end the political stalemate in N.I., and continued through to November .Although they appeared to achieve little the Brooke Mayhew talks were the first to have "three strands", the relationships within Northern Ireland, between Northern Ireland and the Republic, and between London and Dublin. A basis had been laid for future discussions.The CAIN website, whose workers are based at the Magee campus in Derry, provides an extensive range of information and source material on the conflict and politics from  to the present day.The site is used by a worldwide audience and has received more than  million visits since it was launched in March .Earlier this year, the Derry News revealed that it was under threat of closure but thanks to a staunch defence of the site mounted by academics and researchers, Ulster University announced a nine-month reprieve while funding options are explored.Around  documents relating to the years  and  have been added to the CAIN website as part of ongoing work involving the Ulster University and the Public Record Office of Northern Ireland .The latest additions will bring to more than , the number of PRONI records available on CAIN.Dr Brendan Lynn, CAIN Deputy Director, said the archive is delighted to have been able to continue its cooperation with PRONI and to update the existing section with material dealing with the years  and .Mr Lynn commented: â€œCAIN has always sought to work with and iniduals, groups and organisations with relevant information relating to the Northern Ireland â€˜troublesâ€™ in order to make it available on-line.â€œAn obvious example of this has been the partnership that CAIN has developed with The Public Record Office of Northern Ireland . As the official archive for Northern Ireland, one of PRONIâ€™s many responsibilities is to receive government records from the early s onwards and to make them available for researchers.â€œThe development of â€˜PRONI Records on CAINâ€™ therefore provides people with an opportunity to gain access to a selection of material from the official files, that to date, chart the period from  to .â€œLooking ahead both CAIN and PRONI hope to continue this work to enable researchers to examine the events and personalities involved in the evolving â€˜peace processâ€™ of the s which culminated with the signing of the Good Friday Agreement in April .â€â€˜Political stalemateâ€™In terms of the latest documents, one of the most striking features of this material is that some of the issues which are so prominent today are the same ones which confronted politicians and policy makers back then.â€œFor instance the search for an end to the political stalemate in Northern Ireland was dominated by a series of long, drawn out discussions â€“ often referred to as the Brooke Mayhew talks of -. Whilst these were ultimately to end in failure they did leave behind an important template that was to be used at a later date,â€ Mr Lynn added.Dr Michael Willis, PRONI Director, has welcomed the publication of previously secret records through a continuing partnership between PRONI and Conflict Archive on the INternet .He said: â€œPRONIâ€™s mission is to identy, preserve and promote public access to Northern Irelandâ€™s archival heritage.â€œThis latest addition of official documents to the CAIN website enhances the opportunity to view and read key documents from the time. It is an invaluable resource for anyone studying our recent past.â€To access the documents you can visit: https:cain.ulster.ac.uk proni googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh
